shloks.practicalExplanation: Renouncing attachment to results leads to liberation from the cycle of rebirth. This is not fatalism but active engagement without anxious clinging. True freedom is here.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work with full engagement while releasing attachment, moving toward true freedom.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from the cycle of birth and death. Lead me to the state beyond sorrow.

shloks.sanskrit: यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति। तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च॥
shloks.transliteration: yadā te moha-kalilaṁ buddhir vyatitariṣhyati tadā gantāsi nirvedaṁ śhrotavyasya śhrutasya cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: When your intellect crosses beyond the dense forest of delusion, you will become indifferent to all that has been heard and all that is yet to be heard.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Beyond delusion, you transcend even scriptures. The map is no longer needed when you've arrived. The enlightened no longer need external guidance - they are the truth.
shloks.strengthReflection: I use teachings as tools for awakening, not as ends in themselves.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, lead me beyond all delusions to direct realization of truth.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला। समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि॥
shloks.transliteration: śhruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niśhchalā samādhāv achalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi
shloks.simpleMeaning: When your intellect, no longer confused by the variety of scriptural teachings, stands firm and steady in meditation, then you will attain yoga.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When the mind is no longer pulled in different directions by various teachings, when it becomes steady and focused in meditation - that is yoga. Clarity and stillness are the goal.
shloks.strengthReflection: I move toward mental clarity where my mind is no longer pulled by conflicting ideas.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Krishna, stabilize my intellect in steady contemplation of You.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव। स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम्॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣhā samādhi-sthasya keśhava sthita-dhīḥ kiṁ prabhāṣheta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O Keshava, what are the signs of one whose wisdom is steady, who is established in meditation? How does one of steady wisdom speak, sit, and walk?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna asks a brilliant practical question - how can we recognize enlightenment in daily life? What are the visible signs? This begins Krishna's beautiful description of the stable sage.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek not just theory but practical markers of growth and wisdom in daily life.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Keshava, show me the signs of true wisdom so I may recognize and cultivate them.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान्। आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha mano-gatān ātmany evātmanā tuṣhṭaḥ sthita-prajñas tadochyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: O Partha, when one completely gives up all desires of the mind and is satisfied in the self by the self, one is said to be of steady wisdom.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The sage has dropped all mental desires - not through suppression but through finding complete fulfillment within. Self-sufficient in the self - this is the mark of wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek fulfillment from within rather than from endless external desires.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, fill me with such inner satisfaction that external desires naturally fall away.

shloks.sanskrit: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः। वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: duḥkheṣhv anudvigna-manāḥ sukheṣhu vigata-spṛihaḥ vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: One whose mind is not disturbed by sorrow, who does not crave pleasure, and who is free from attachment, fear, and anger - such a sage is called one of steady wisdom.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The sage is not shaken by sorrow or excited by pleasure. Free from attachment, fear, and anger - the three great disturbers of peace. This is emotional mastery.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work to remain unshaken by sorrow, unexcited by pleasure, free from fear and anger.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from the grip of attachment, fear, and anger. Grant me steady wisdom.

shloks.sanskrit: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्। नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
shloks.transliteration: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tat tat prāpya śhubhāśhubham nābhinandati na dveṣhṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who is without attachment everywhere, who neither rejoices nor hates on obtaining good or evil, is firmly established in wisdom.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Equal response to good and evil fortune - no excessive joy or hatred. This is not indifference but a deeper stability that sees beyond surface events.
shloks.strengthReflection: I receive both favorable and unfavorable experiences with equanimity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, establish me in wisdom that sees beyond surface good and evil.

shloks.sanskrit: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
shloks.transliteration: yadā saṁharate chāyaṁ kūrmo 'ṅgānīva sarvaśhaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
shloks.simpleMeaning: When one withdraws the senses from sense objects like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs, one's wisdom is firmly established.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The tortoise withdraws its limbs when threatened. Similarly, the sage can withdraw attention from the senses at will. This is mastery over the senses, not denial of them.
shloks.strengthReflection: I develop the ability to withdraw my attention from external distractions at will.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me the ability to turn my senses inward toward You.

shloks.sanskrit: विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः। रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते॥
shloks.transliteration: viṣhayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ rasa-varjaṁ raso 'py asya paraṁ dṛiṣhṭvā nivartate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sense objects turn away from the abstinent, though the taste for them remains. But even this taste ceases for one who has seen the Supreme.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Merely avoiding sense objects doesn't remove the craving. True freedom comes only when one tastes something higher. When you've found the infinite, finite pleasures naturally lose their grip.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek higher experiences that naturally make lower cravings fade away.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, grant me a taste of Your divine bliss that makes all lesser pleasures pale.

shloks.sanskrit: यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः। इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः॥
shloks.transliteration: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣhasya vipaśhchitaḥ indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṁ manaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: O son of Kunti, the turbulent senses can forcibly carry away the mind of even a discerning person who is striving for self-control.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Even the wisest and most disciplined can be overpowered by the senses. This is a warning against complacency. Vigilance must be constant.
shloks.strengthReflection: I remain vigilant knowing that even the wise can be overpowered by senses.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Kaunteya's Lord, protect me from the powerful force of the senses.

shloks.sanskrit: तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः। वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
shloks.transliteration: tāni sarvāṇi saṁyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ vaśhe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Having controlled all the senses, one should sit in meditation with Me as the supreme goal. One who has mastered the senses is established in wisdom.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The solution: control senses, focus on the Divine. Making God the supreme goal naturally brings sense control. It's not about suppression but redirection toward the highest.
shloks.strengthReflection: I redirect my senses toward higher goals rather than simply suppressing them.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are my supreme goal. With my senses fixed on You, I find stability.

shloks.sanskrit: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते। सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते॥
shloks.transliteration: dhyāyato viṣhayān puṁsaḥ saṅgas teṣhūpajāyate saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodho 'bhijāyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: When a person dwells on sense objects, attachment develops. From attachment arises desire, and from unfulfilled desire comes anger.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Here is the chain reaction: thinking leads to attachment, attachment to desire, unfulfilled desire to anger. Guard your thoughts - they are the first link in the chain of bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: I guard the gates of my mind, knowing that my attention shapes my reality.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, anchor my mind in thoughts of You. Break the chain of bondage.

shloks.sanskrit: क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः। स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति॥
shloks.transliteration: krodhād bhavati sammohaḥ sammohāt smṛiti-vibhramaḥ smṛiti-bhraṁśhād buddhi-nāśho buddhi-nāśhāt praṇaśhyati
shloks.simpleMeaning: From anger arises delusion; from delusion, confusion of memory; from confusion of memory, destruction of intelligence; and from destruction of intelligence, one perishes.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The chain continues: anger causes delusion, delusion causes memory loss, memory loss destroys intelligence, and without intelligence comes complete destruction. This is the downward spiral.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize and interrupt the downward spiral before anger leads to self-destruction.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, protect me from the destructive spiral of anger and delusion.

shloks.sanskrit: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्। आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति॥
shloks.transliteration: rāga-dveṣha-viyuktais tu viṣhayān indriyaiśh charan ātma-vaśhyair vidheyātmā prasādam adhigachchhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: But one who controls the mind and moves among sense objects with senses freed from attachment and aversion attains divine grace and inner peace.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The disciplined person can engage with the world without being trapped by attraction or aversion. This is not withdrawal but mastery - participating in life without bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: I engage with the world freely, without being controlled by attraction or repulsion.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, free me from likes and dislikes. Let me move through the world with inner peace.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते। प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते॥
shloks.transliteration: prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir asyopajāyate prasanna-chetaso hy āśhu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣhṭhate
shloks.simpleMeaning: In that peace, all sorrows are destroyed, for the intellect of the tranquil-minded soon becomes firmly established.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Inner peace destroys sorrow and stabilizes intelligence. Peace is not just a pleasant feeling - it is the foundation for clarity and wisdom. Cultivate peace first.
shloks.strengthReflection: I prioritize inner peace, knowing it is the foundation for clarity and wisdom.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me Your peace, in which all sorrows dissolve.

shloks.sanskrit: नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना। न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम्॥
shloks.transliteration: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na chāyuktasya bhāvanā na chābhāvayataḥ śhāntir aśhāntasya kutaḥ sukham
shloks.simpleMeaning: There is no wisdom for the undisciplined, and no contemplation for the undisciplined. Without contemplation there is no peace, and without peace, how can there be happiness?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Without discipline there is no wisdom. Without wisdom no contemplation. Without contemplation no peace. Without peace no happiness. The chain is clear - discipline is the foundation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I embrace discipline as the foundation for wisdom, peace, and true happiness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me build the discipline that leads to wisdom, peace, and joy.

shloks.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते। तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि॥
shloks.transliteration: indriyāṇāṁ hi charatāṁ yan mano 'nuvidhīyate tad asya harati prajñāṁ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi
shloks.simpleMeaning: When the mind runs after the wandering senses, it carries away wisdom like wind carries away a ship on water.
shloks.practicalExplanation: A mind following the senses is like a ship without anchor - blown wherever the wind takes it. Control comes from anchoring the mind, not just restraining the senses.
shloks.strengthReflection: I anchor my mind firmly so it is not carried away by sensory impulses.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, be the anchor of my mind in the stormy sea of sense impressions.

shloks.sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
shloks.transliteration: tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛihītāni sarvaśhaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣhṭhitā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Therefore, O mighty-armed one, one whose senses are completely restrained from their objects is established in wisdom.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Complete sense restraint establishes wisdom. This doesn't mean we stop experiencing - it means we stop being controlled. The senses become servants, not masters.
shloks.strengthReflection: I make my senses my servants rather than my masters.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Mighty-armed Lord, help me master my senses for wisdom and peace.

shloks.sanskrit: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी। यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः॥
shloks.transliteration: yā niśhā sarva-bhūtānāṁ tasyāṁ jāgarti saṁyamī yasyāṁ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśhā paśhyato muneḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: What is night for all beings is the time of awakening for the self-controlled; and the time when all beings are awake is night for the seeing sage.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The sage and ordinary people live in opposite realities. What excites the worldly is meaningless to the wise; what fulfills the sage is invisible to the worldly. Choose which world you want to live in.
shloks.strengthReflection: I awaken to what truly matters rather than following the sleeping masses.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, awaken me to the reality that the world sleeps to.

shloks.sanskrit: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्। तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी॥
shloks.transliteration: āpūryamāṇam achala-pratiṣhṭhaṁ samudram āpaḥ praviśhanti yadvat tadvat kāmā yaṁ praviśhanti sarve sa śhāntim āpnoti na kāma-kāmī
shloks.simpleMeaning: Just as waters enter the ocean, which is full and still, so too desires enter the sage who remains unmoved. Such a person attains peace, not one who craves desires.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The ocean receives all rivers but remains full and still. Similarly, the sage experiences desires without being disturbed. Desires come; the sage remains stable. This is true peace.
shloks.strengthReflection: Like the ocean, I remain full and stable even as desires flow through me.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, make me like the ocean - full of You, unmoved by the rivers of desire.

shloks.sanskrit: विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः। निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति॥
shloks.transliteration: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṁśh charati niḥspṛihaḥ nirmamo nirahankāraḥ sa śhāntim adhigachchhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who gives up all selfish desires, and lives free from longing, free from 'mine' and 'ego,' attains peace.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Three things to release: desires, possessiveness ('mine'), and ego ('I'). With these gone, peace is natural. These three are the root of all restlessness.
shloks.strengthReflection: I release attachment to desires, possessions, and ego-identity to find true peace.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, free me from 'I', 'me', and 'mine'. In this emptiness, fill me with Your peace.

shloks.sanskrit: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति। स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति॥
shloks.transliteration: eṣhā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṁ prāpya vimuhyati sthitvāsyām anta-kāle 'pi brahma-nirvāṇam ṛichchhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: O Partha, this is the state of realizing Brahman. Having attained this, one is never again confused. Being established in this state even at the moment of death, one attains liberation in Brahman.
shloks.practicalExplanation: This divine state, once attained, is never lost. Even if achieved only at death, it leads to liberation. But why wait? Begin now and live in freedom. This is the Brahmic state - the goal of life.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work toward the ultimate state of consciousness where confusion and suffering end forever.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Partha's Lord, establish me in the Brahmic state, now and at the hour of death.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन। तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha jyāyasī chet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana tat kiṁ karmaṇi ghore māṁ niyojayasi keśhava
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O Janardana, if You consider knowledge superior to action, why then do You ask me to engage in this terrible war, O Keshava?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna is confused - if wisdom is higher than action, why fight? This is a common misunderstanding. True wisdom expresses through right action, not inaction.
shloks.strengthReflection: I understand that true wisdom is demonstrated through right action, not through avoidance.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Keshava, clarify my confusion between knowledge and action.

shloks.sanskrit: व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे। तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम्॥
shloks.transliteration: vyāmiśhreṇeva vākyena buddhiṁ mohayasīva me tad ekaṁ vada niśhchitya yena śhreyo 'ham āpnuyām
shloks.simpleMeaning: My intellect is confused by Your ambiguous words. Tell me decisively that one path by which I can attain the highest good.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna wants one clear path. But life isn't that simple - different situations require different approaches. The wise integrate multiple truths rather than seeking oversimplification.
shloks.strengthReflection: I embrace complexity rather than demanding oversimplified answers.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, give me clarity that embraces the wholeness of truth.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ। ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम्॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha loke 'smin dvi-vidhā niṣhṭhā purā proktā mayānagha jñāna-yogena sāṅkhyānāṁ karma-yogena yoginām
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: O sinless one, I have previously explained two paths for the world — the path of knowledge for the contemplative and the path of action for the active.
shloks.practicalExplanation: There are two valid paths: knowledge for the contemplative mind, action for the active personality. Both lead to the same goal. Choose according to your nature.
shloks.strengthReflection: I choose the path that suits my nature, knowing all sincere paths lead to truth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, guide me to the path most suited to my nature.

shloks.sanskrit: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते। न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति॥
shloks.transliteration: na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣhkarmyaṁ puruṣho 'śhnute na cha sannyasanād eva siddhiṁ samadhigachchhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: Not by merely abstaining from action does one attain freedom from karma, nor does one attain perfection by mere renunciation.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Running away from action doesn't free you from karma. External renunciation without internal transformation is useless. True freedom comes from how you act, not whether you act.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek freedom through transformed action, not through avoidance.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, free me from karma through wisdom in action, not escape from action.

shloks.sanskrit: न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्। कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः॥
shloks.transliteration: na hi kaśhchit kṣhaṇam api jātu tiṣhṭhaty akarma-kṛit kāryate hy avaśhaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛiti-jair guṇaiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Indeed, no one can remain without action even for a moment. Everyone is driven to act helplessly by the qualities born of material nature.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Complete inaction is impossible - even sitting still involves action. Nature forces us to act. Since action is inevitable, the question is not whether to act but how to act wisely.
shloks.strengthReflection: Since I must act anyway, I choose to act consciously and wisely.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, since I cannot escape action, teach me to act in alignment with Your will.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्। इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: karmendriyāṇi saṁyamya ya āste manasā smaran indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā mithyāchāraḥ sa uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who restrains the organs of action but mentally dwells on sense objects is deluded and is called a hypocrite.
shloks.practicalExplanation: External restraint with internal craving is hypocrisy. What matters is where your mind dwells, not just what your body does. Inner and outer must align.
shloks.strengthReflection: I align my inner thoughts with my outer actions, avoiding the trap of hypocrisy.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, purify both my actions and my thoughts. Let me be authentic within and without.

shloks.sanskrit: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन। कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: yas tv indriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate 'rjuna karmendriyaiḥ karma-yogam asaktaḥ sa viśhiṣhyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: But one who controls the senses with the mind, O Arjuna, and engages the organs of action in karma yoga without attachment — such a person excels.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The superior path: control the mind, then engage in action without attachment. This is karma yoga - working fully while remaining inwardly free. Excellence through detached engagement.
shloks.strengthReflection: I engage fully in action while maintaining inner detachment from results.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Arjuna's guide, help me master karma yoga - full engagement with complete detachment.

shloks.sanskrit: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः। शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः॥
shloks.transliteration: niyataṁ kuru karma tvaṁ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ śharīra-yātrāpi cha te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Perform your prescribed duties, for action is superior to inaction. Even the maintenance of your body would not be possible through inaction.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Do your duty! Action is always better than inaction. Even basic survival requires action. The path is through engagement, not withdrawal.
shloks.strengthReflection: I embrace my duties knowing that active engagement is always superior to avoidance.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, I will perform my duties. Guide me in right action.

shloks.sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः। तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर॥
shloks.transliteration: yajñārthāt karmaṇo 'nyatra loko 'yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ tad-arthaṁ karma kaunteya mukta-saṅgaḥ samāchara
shloks.simpleMeaning: Work done as a sacrifice for the Supreme frees one from bondage. Therefore, O son of Kunti, perform your duties for His sake, free from attachment.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Action binds only when done selfishly. Action done as offering to the Divine liberates. The same action produces bondage or freedom depending on the spirit behind it.
shloks.strengthReflection: I transform ordinary work into sacred offering by dedicating it to a higher purpose.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Kaunteya's Lord, I offer all my actions to You. Accept them as my sacrifice.

shloks.sanskrit: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः। अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक्॥
shloks.transliteration: saha-yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛiṣhṭvā purovācha prajāpatiḥ anena prasaviṣhyadhvam eṣha vo 'stv iṣhṭa-kāma-dhuk
shloks.simpleMeaning: In the beginning, the Creator created humanity together with sacrifice and said: By this shall you prosper; may this fulfill all your desires.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Humanity was created with the principle of sacrifice. Giving, not just taking, is built into our nature. Prosperity comes through contribution, not accumulation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I prosper by contributing, not just by accumulating.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, teach me the spirit of sacrifice that brings true prosperity.

shloks.sanskrit: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः। परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ॥
shloks.transliteration: devān bhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ parasparaṁ bhāvayantaḥ śhreyaḥ param avāpsyatha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Nourish the gods with sacrifice, and the gods will nourish you. By nourishing one another, you will attain the supreme good.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The universe operates on reciprocity. Give and receive. When we contribute to the cosmic order, it supports us in return. Mutual nourishment creates prosperity for all.
shloks.strengthReflection: I participate in the cycle of giving and receiving that sustains all life.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let me be part of the cosmic exchange of giving and receiving.

shloks.sanskrit: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः। तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः॥
shloks.transliteration: iṣhṭān bhogān hi vo devā dāsyante yajña-bhāvitāḥ tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Nourished by sacrifice, the gods will give you desired enjoyments. One who enjoys their gifts without giving back is verily a thief.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Taking without giving back makes you a thief. This applies to all of life - resources, relationships, communities. Contribution is not optional; it's an ethical obligation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I give back for what I receive. I am not a taker but a contributor.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, save me from being a thief. Help me give back to life what life gives me.

shloks.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः। भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात्॥
shloks.transliteration: yajña-śhiṣhṭāśhinaḥ santo muchyante sarva-kilbiṣhaiḥ bhuñjate te tv aghaṁ pāpā ye pachanty ātma-kāraṇāt
shloks.simpleMeaning: The righteous who eat the remnants of sacrifice are freed from all sins. But those who cook only for themselves eat only sin.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those who first offer and then enjoy are freed from sin. Those who consume only for self-interest accumulate negativity. Share before you consume.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice offering before consuming - in food, resources, and all of life.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let me always offer first and then enjoy what remains.

shloks.sanskrit: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः। यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः॥
shloks.transliteration: annād bhavanti bhūtāni parjanyād anna-sambhavaḥ yajñād bhavati parjanyo yajñaḥ karma-samudbhavaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: All beings are sustained by food; food is produced by rain; rain comes from sacrifice; sacrifice is born of action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Everything is interconnected in a cosmic cycle. Our actions participate in this cycle. When we act rightly, we support the entire web of existence.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize my actions as part of a cosmic interconnection affecting all life.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let my actions support and nourish the great chain of being.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्। तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
shloks.transliteration: karma brahmodbhavaṁ viddhi brahmākṣhara-samudbhavam tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣhṭhitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Know that prescribed duties arise from the Vedas, and the Vedas come from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervading Brahman is eternally established in sacrifice.
shloks.practicalExplanation: All duty originates from the Divine. The cosmic order is sustained by sacrifice. When we fulfill our duties, we participate in this divine order.
shloks.strengthReflection: My duties connect me to the cosmic order and the Divine.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I see Your presence in all duty. Let my work be my worship.

shloks.sanskrit: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः। अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति॥
shloks.transliteration: evaṁ pravartitaṁ chakraṁ nānuvartayatīha yaḥ aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṁ pārtha sa jīvati
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who does not follow this established cycle of sacrifice, living a life of sin and sense pleasure, lives in vain, O Partha.
shloks.practicalExplanation: To refuse participation in the cosmic order while enjoying its benefits is to live in vain. We cannot opt out of giving while continuing to receive.
shloks.strengthReflection: I refuse to live a meaningless life of pure consumption. I participate and contribute.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, save me from a futile existence. Let me participate meaningfully in Your cosmic dance.

shloks.sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः। आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: yas tv ātma-ratir eva syād ātma-tṛiptaśh cha mānavaḥ ātmany eva cha santuṣhṭas tasya kāryaṁ na vidyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: But for one who delights in the Self alone, who is satisfied with the Self, and who is content in the Self — for such a person, there is no duty.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The fully self-realized person has no obligatory duties because they have transcended all personal needs. But until that point, duty remains binding. Don't pretend enlightenment you haven't achieved.
shloks.strengthReflection: Until I reach full self-realization, I embrace my duties without excuses.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, until I am fully established in You, guide me in faithful performance of duty.

shloks.sanskrit: नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन। न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः॥
shloks.transliteration: naiva tasya kṛitenārtho nākṛiteneha kaśhchana na chāsya sarva-bhūteṣhu kaśhchid artha-vyapāśhrayaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Such a self-realized person has nothing to gain from action or inaction, nor does such a person depend on any being for any purpose.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The enlightened person gains nothing from action and loses nothing from inaction. Complete independence from all needs and beings. This is the ultimate freedom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I move toward independence from outcomes while remaining engaged in life.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, bring me to that state where I need nothing from anyone except You.

shloks.sanskrit: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर। असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः॥
shloks.transliteration: tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samāchara asakto hy ācharan karma param āpnoti puruṣhaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Therefore, always perform your duty without attachment. By working without attachment, a person attains the Supreme.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The formula is clear: constant duty, zero attachment. Do what needs to be done, but don't cling to results. This path leads to the highest realization.
shloks.strengthReflection: I perform necessary duties consistently while releasing attachment to outcomes.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, I act in Your service, leaving results to You.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः। लोकसङ्ग्रहमेवापि सम्पश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि॥
shloks.transliteration: karmaṇaiva hi sansiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśhyan kartum arhasi
shloks.simpleMeaning: King Janaka and others attained perfection through action. You should also act for the welfare of the world.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Great souls like Janaka achieved liberation while actively ruling kingdoms. Work for the world's welfare, not just personal liberation. True spirituality embraces both.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work for the benefit of others, not just for my own spiritual progress.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let my actions serve the welfare of the world.

shloks.sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः। स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते॥
shloks.transliteration: yad yad ācharati śhreṣhṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Whatever a great person does, common people follow. Whatever standards such a person sets, the world pursues.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Leaders set examples. Whatever influential people do, others imitate. Therefore, leaders have extra responsibility to act rightly. Your influence shapes others.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize my influence on others and act as a positive example.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let my actions be worthy of imitation. Make me a positive influence.

shloks.sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन। नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि॥
shloks.transliteration: na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣhu lokeṣhu kiñchana nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva cha karmaṇi
shloks.simpleMeaning: O Partha, there is nothing in the three worlds that I need to do, nothing left for Me to attain. Yet I continue to act.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna, the Supreme, has nothing to accomplish yet continues to act. Action is not just for gaining something - it is a mode of being, of contribution, of expression.
shloks.strengthReflection: I act not just to gain but to express, contribute, and participate in life.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord who needs nothing yet acts, teach me selfless action.

shloks.sanskrit: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
shloks.transliteration: yadi hy ahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ mama vartmānuvartante manuṣhyāḥ pārtha sarvaśhaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: If I did not engage in action tirelessly, O Partha, people would follow My path in every way.
shloks.practicalExplanation: If the Divine stopped working, people would think inaction is acceptable. Leaders cannot afford to set bad examples. Responsibility grows with influence.
shloks.strengthReflection: I maintain active engagement, knowing others may follow my example.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me be tireless in right action as You are.

shloks.sanskrit: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्। सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः॥
shloks.transliteration: utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ched aham saṅkarasya cha kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: If I ceased to act, these worlds would perish. I would be the cause of confusion and the destruction of all people.
shloks.practicalExplanation: If the Divine stopped maintaining cosmic order, chaos would result. Similarly, when we abandon our duties, we contribute to social disorder. Our actions matter.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize that my actions support the order of my world. I act responsibly.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me understand how my actions support the greater order.

shloks.sanskrit: सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत। कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसङ्ग्रहम्॥
shloks.transliteration: saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvānso yathā kurvanti bhārata kuryād vidvāns tathāsaktas chikīrṣhur loka-saṅgraham
shloks.simpleMeaning: As the ignorant act with attachment, O Bharata, so should the wise act without attachment, for the welfare of the world.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Both wise and ignorant engage in action. The difference is attachment. The wise work equally hard but for the world's benefit, not personal gain.
shloks.strengthReflection: I match the intensity of action of worldly people but direct it toward higher purposes.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let me work as hard as anyone but for purposes that serve all.

shloks.sanskrit: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्। जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्तः समाचरन्॥
shloks.transliteration: na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām joṣhayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācharan
shloks.simpleMeaning: The wise should not unsettle the minds of the ignorant who are attached to action. Rather, by performing duties steadily, they should inspire others to act.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Don't confuse beginners with advanced teachings they can't apply. Meet people where they are. Lead by example rather than preaching beyond people's capacity.
shloks.strengthReflection: I help others grow gradually, meeting them where they are, leading by example.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, give me wisdom to guide others appropriately without causing confusion.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः। अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: prakṛiteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśhaḥ ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: All actions are performed by the three modes of material nature. But one deluded by ego thinks 'I am the doer.'
shloks.practicalExplanation: Nature does everything through its qualities. The ego falsely claims doership. When we think 'I am acting,' we are confused. Understanding this frees us from the burden of doership.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize that actions happen through nature. I release the burden of being 'the doer.'
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, free me from the ego that claims doership. Let me see Your hand in all action.

shloks.sanskrit: तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः। गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते॥
shloks.transliteration: tattva-vit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ guṇā guṇeṣhu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate
shloks.simpleMeaning: But one who knows the truth about the divisions of the modes of nature and their actions, O mighty-armed one, understanding that it is the modes acting upon each other, does not become attached.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The wise see that it's qualities (gunas) interacting with qualities. Senses perceiving objects, that's all. Seeing this truth removes attachment and creates inner freedom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I observe actions as natural interactions of energies, reducing my attachment to outcomes.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Mighty-armed, grant me this vision that sees beyond personal involvement.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु। तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्॥
shloks.transliteration: prakṛiter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu tān akṛitsna-vido mandān kṛitsna-vin na vichālayet
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those deluded by the modes of material nature become attached to material actions. The wise should not unsettle these less intelligent people who do not understand the complete truth.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Don't disturb those who can't yet grasp higher truths. Respect where people are in their journey. Advanced teachings given prematurely can cause confusion and harm.
shloks.strengthReflection: I respect each person's stage of development and share wisdom appropriately.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, grant me patience and wisdom in helping others grow at their own pace.

shloks.sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा। निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः॥
shloks.transliteration: mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasyādhyātma-chetasā nirāśhīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Surrendering all actions to Me, with your mind fixed on the Self, free from desire and selfishness, fight without mental fever.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The complete formula: surrender all actions to God, focus on the Self, release desire and possessiveness, and act without anxiety. This is the essence of karma yoga.
shloks.strengthReflection: I surrender my actions to the Divine, releasing desire and anxiety.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I surrender all my actions to You. Free from anxiety, I engage in my duty.

shloks.sanskrit: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः॥
shloks.transliteration: ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣhṭhanti mānavāḥ śhraddhāvanto 'nasūyanto muchyante te 'pi karmabhiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those who constantly follow this teaching of Mine with faith and without envy are freed from the bondage of actions.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Faith and freedom from envy are keys. Follow these teachings with genuine trust and openness, and freedom from karma is assured. Consistency matters.
shloks.strengthReflection: I follow this wisdom with faith and without envy, trusting in eventual freedom.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, with faith and without jealousy, I follow Your teaching. Free me from karmic bondage.

shloks.sanskrit: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्। सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः॥
shloks.transliteration: ye tv etad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣhṭhanti me matam sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāns tān viddhi naṣhṭān achetasaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: But those who criticize this teaching and do not follow it, know them to be devoid of all knowledge, deluded, and doomed.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rejecting wisdom while criticizing it leads to destruction. Some people prefer comfortable ignorance to challenging truth. They lose both knowledge and growth.
shloks.strengthReflection: I remain open to wisdom that challenges me, avoiding the trap of dismissive criticism.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, save me from the closed-mindedness that rejects Your divine wisdom.

shloks.sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि। प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति॥
shloks.transliteration: sadṛiśhaṁ cheṣhṭate svasyāḥ prakṛiter jñānavān api prakṛitiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣhyati
shloks.simpleMeaning: Even a person of knowledge acts according to their own nature. All beings follow their nature. What can repression accomplish?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Everyone acts according to nature. Forced repression doesn't work long-term. Real change comes through understanding and gradual transformation, not suppression.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work with my nature rather than against it, transforming gradually through understanding.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me transform my nature from within rather than merely suppressing it.

shloks.sanskrit: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ। तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ॥
shloks.transliteration: indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāga-dveṣhau vyavasthitau tayor na vaśham āgachchhet tau hy asya paripanthinau
shloks.simpleMeaning: Attachment and aversion toward sense objects are seated in the senses. One should not come under their sway, for they are obstacles on the path.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Attraction and aversion are natural to the senses, but don't let them control you. They are roadblocks on the spiritual path. Recognize them without obeying them.
shloks.strengthReflection: I observe my attractions and aversions without being controlled by them.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, free me from the tyranny of likes and dislikes that block my path to You.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः॥
shloks.transliteration: śhreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt svanuṣhṭhitāt sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śhreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: It is better to perform one's own duty imperfectly than to perform another's duty perfectly. Death in one's own duty is preferable; another's duty is fraught with danger.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Stick to your own path, even if imperfect. Imitating others' paths leads to danger. Your unique duty, even if challenging, is your true path to growth.
shloks.strengthReflection: I embrace my unique path and purpose, not envying or imitating others.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me find and follow my sva-dharma, my own true path.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः। अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha atha kena prayukto 'yaṁ pāpaṁ charati pūruṣhaḥ anichchhann api vārṣhṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O descendant of Vrishni, what compels a person to commit sin, even against their will, as if driven by force?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna asks the crucial question: why do we do wrong even when we don't want to? What force compels us against our better judgment? This begins the exploration of inner enemies.
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine the forces that compel me toward actions against my values.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, reveal to me what forces compel me to act against my true nature.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः। महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha kāma eṣha krodha eṣha rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ mahāśhano mahā-pāpmā viddhy enam iha vairiṇam
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: It is desire, it is anger, born of the mode of passion. It is all-devouring and the greatest sin. Know this as the enemy here.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna identifies the enemy: desire and its offspring, anger. They come from rajas (passion) and are insatiable and sinful. Knowing your enemy is the first step to victory.
shloks.strengthReflection: I identify desire and anger as my inner enemies and resolve to overcome them.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me conquer the enemies of desire and anger that dwell within me.

shloks.sanskrit: धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च। यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśho malena cha yatholbenāvṛito garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: As fire is covered by smoke, a mirror by dust, and an embryo by the womb, so knowledge is covered by desire.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Three metaphors show how desire obscures knowledge: smoke covers fire, dust covers a mirror, the womb covers an embryo. The covering can be thin or thick, but it always obscures.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize how desire clouds my knowledge and judgment. I work to clear the covering.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, clear away the smoke of desire that obscures Your light within me.

shloks.sanskrit: आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा। कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च॥
shloks.transliteration: āvṛitaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣhpūreṇānalena cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: O son of Kunti, knowledge is covered by this eternal enemy of the wise, taking the form of desire, which is as insatiable as fire.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Desire is the eternal enemy of the wise - never satisfied, always burning. Like fire that consumes more fuel and grows larger, desire fed grows rather than diminishes.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize that feeding desire only makes it grow. I practice restraint.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Kaunteya's Lord, extinguish the fire of insatiable desire within me.

shloks.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते। एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्॥
shloks.transliteration: indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣhṭhānam uchyate etair vimohayaty eṣha jñānam āvṛitya dehinam
shloks.simpleMeaning: The senses, mind, and intellect are said to be its seats. Through these, desire covers knowledge and deludes the embodied soul.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Desire operates through senses, mind, and intellect - our entire apparatus of experience and decision. It covers knowledge at every level. We must guard all three.
shloks.strengthReflection: I guard my senses, mind, and intellect from the invasion of consuming desire.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, protect my senses, mind, and intellect from the enemy of desire.

shloks.sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ। पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्॥
shloks.transliteration: tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣhabha pāpmānaṁ prajahi hy enaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśhanam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, first controlling the senses, slay this sinful destroyer of knowledge and self-realization.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The practical instruction: first control the senses, then destroy desire. Start at the outer gate. If you can't control what enters through the senses, the inner battle is already lost.
shloks.strengthReflection: I begin by controlling my senses, the outer gate through which desire enters.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Best of Bharatas' guide, help me control my senses and destroy the enemy of desire.

shloks.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः। मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः॥
shloks.transliteration: indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ manasas tu parā buddhir yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and that which is superior to the intellect is the soul.
shloks.practicalExplanation: A hierarchy: body < senses < mind < intellect < soul. Control the higher to master the lower. The soul, your true self, can master intellect, which masters mind, which masters senses.
shloks.strengthReflection: I identify with my highest self, which has power over intellect, mind, and senses.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, awaken me to my soul's power over all lower faculties.

shloks.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना। जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम्॥
shloks.transliteration: evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā saṁstabhyātmānam ātmanā jahi śhatruṁ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Thus knowing the soul to be superior to the intellect, steady the self by the self. O mighty-armed one, slay the enemy in the form of desire, which is difficult to overcome.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Know the soul's supremacy, stabilize yourself in that identity, and from there conquer desire. It's difficult but possible when fighting from the highest ground of soul-awareness.
shloks.strengthReflection: From the position of my highest self, I conquer the difficult enemy of desire.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Mighty-armed Lord, I take refuge in the soul's power. Help me slay the enemy of desire.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्। विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha imaṁ vivasvate yogaṁ proktavān aham avyayam vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣhvākave 'bravīt
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: I taught this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan the sun-god, who taught it to Manu, who taught it to Ikshvaku.
shloks.practicalExplanation: This wisdom is ancient and eternal, passed down through a divine lineage. It is not new philosophy but timeless truth preserved through worthy recipients.
shloks.strengthReflection: I receive this ancient wisdom with humility, becoming part of an eternal lineage.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I receive with reverence the wisdom You have preserved through ages.

shloks.sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः। स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप॥
shloks.transliteration: evaṁ paramparā-prāptam imaṁ rājarṣhayo viduḥ sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣhṭaḥ parantapa
shloks.simpleMeaning: This supreme science was thus received through the chain of disciplic succession, and the saintly kings understood it that way. But in course of time, O Arjuna, it was lost.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Wisdom degrades over time without proper transmission. Each generation must reconnect with the source. Krishna speaks to restore what was lost.
shloks.strengthReflection: I treasure sacred teachings, knowing they can be obscured without care.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, revive in me the wisdom that time and negligence have obscured.

shloks.sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः। भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्॥
shloks.transliteration: sa evāyaṁ mayā te 'dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ bhakto 'si me sakhā cheti rahasyaṁ hy etad uttamam
shloks.simpleMeaning: That very ancient science is today told by Me to you because you are My devotee and friend. This is a supreme secret.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Devotion and friendship with the Divine open access to supreme secrets. This wisdom is not for the casual but for those with genuine connection.
shloks.strengthReflection: Through devotion and inner friendship with Truth, I open myself to deeper wisdom.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Krishna, as Your devotee and friend, I receive this supreme secret.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः। कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha aparaṁ bhavato janma paraṁ janma vivasvataḥ katham etad vijānīyāṁ tvam ādau proktavān iti
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: Your birth is recent, while Vivasvan's birth is ancient. How am I to understand that You taught this yoga in the beginning?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna questions reasonably - how could Krishna have taught the sun-god millions of years ago? This sets up Krishna's revelation of His eternal nature.
shloks.strengthReflection: I question respectfully to deepen understanding, not dismiss.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me understand Your eternal nature beyond appearances.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन। तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava chārjuna tāny ahaṁ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṁ vettha parantapa
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: Many births have passed for you and for Me, O Arjuna. I know them all; you do not, O scorcher of foes.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna reveals: we've had many lives. He remembers all; Arjuna doesn't. The enlightened consciousness transcends the forgetfulness of multiple incarnations.
shloks.strengthReflection: I exist beyond this one life. My soul carries wisdom from countless experiences.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord who remembers all, awaken in me the wisdom of my eternal journey.

shloks.sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्। प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया॥
shloks.transliteration: ajo 'pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśhvaro 'pi san prakṛitiṁ svām adhiṣhṭhāya sambhavāmy ātma-māyayā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Although I am unborn, imperishable, and the Lord of all beings, I manifest Myself by controlling My own material nature through My divine power.
shloks.practicalExplanation: God incarnates not by karma but by choice. Through divine will, the unborn appears as born, the timeless enters time. This is the mystery of divine incarnation.
shloks.strengthReflection: The Divine chooses to appear in forms I can relate to, out of compassion.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Unborn Lord, thank You for appearing in forms I can love and worship.

shloks.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛijāmy aham
shloks.simpleMeaning: Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness rises, O Bharata, at that time I manifest Myself.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When darkness rises, light appears. The Divine intervenes at crucial moments in cosmic history. This is the promise that good will never be permanently defeated.
shloks.strengthReflection: In times of moral confusion, I trust that divine guidance will appear.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, appear in my life when I lose my way. Restore dharma within me.

shloks.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे॥
shloks.transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśhāya cha duṣhkṛitām dharma-sansthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge
shloks.simpleMeaning: To protect the righteous, to destroy the wicked, and to establish dharma, I appear in every age.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The Divine comes for three purposes: protect the good, destroy evil, establish dharma. In every era, this rebalancing occurs. We are never abandoned.
shloks.strengthReflection: I align with righteousness, trusting divine protection and support.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord who appears age after age, protect me and establish dharma through me.

shloks.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन॥
shloks.transliteration: janma karma cha me divyam evaṁ yo vetti tattvataḥ tyaktvā dehaṁ punar janma naiti mām eti so 'rjuna
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who truly understands My divine birth and activities, O Arjuna, upon leaving the body, is not reborn but comes to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Understanding Krishna's divine nature liberates from rebirth. This is not mere intellectual knowledge but deep realization of the divine mystery.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek not just information but transformative understanding that liberates.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me truly know Your divine nature and attain You.

shloks.sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः। बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः॥
shloks.transliteration: vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśhritāḥ bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Free from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, many have become purified by the austerity of wisdom and attained My divine nature.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Many have achieved liberation through this path. It requires releasing attachment, fear, and anger, becoming absorbed in the Divine, purified by wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work to free myself from attachment, fear, and anger to realize divine nature.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, purify me through wisdom. Free me from passion, fear, and anger.

shloks.sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
shloks.transliteration: ye yathā māṁ prapadyante tāns tathaiva bhajāmy aham mama vartmānuvartante manuṣhyāḥ pārtha sarvaśhaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: In whatever way people surrender to Me, I reciprocate accordingly. Everyone follows My path in all respects, O Partha.
shloks.practicalExplanation: God responds according to how we approach Him. All paths ultimately lead to the Divine. The Divine meets seekers wherever they are.
shloks.strengthReflection: I approach the Divine in my authentic way, trusting that reciprocation will come.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I surrender to You in my own way. Please respond to my seeking.

shloks.sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः। क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा॥
shloks.transliteration: kāṅkṣhantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ yajanta iha devatāḥ kṣhipraṁ hi mānuṣhe loke siddhir bhavati karmajā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those desiring success in actions worship the gods, for in this human world, success from action comes quickly.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Worldly people worship gods for quick results. Material success comes faster than spiritual, but spiritual success is more lasting.
shloks.strengthReflection: I pursue both material goals and spiritual growth, understanding each has its place.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, while I work in the world, never let me forget the higher goal.

shloks.sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः। तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्॥
shloks.transliteration: chātur-varṇyaṁ mayā sṛiṣhṭaṁ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśhaḥ tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhy akartāram avyayam
shloks.simpleMeaning: The four divisions of human society were created by Me according to differences in qualities and activities. Know that though I am the creator, I am the non-doer and eternal.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Social divisions are based on qualities and work, not birth. The Divine creates but remains uninvolved in the drama. Action and non-action coexist in the Divine.
shloks.strengthReflection: My role in society is determined by my qualities and actions, not my birth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me find my true place in society according to my nature.

shloks.sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा। इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: na māṁ karmāṇi limpanti na me karma-phale spṛihā iti māṁ yo 'bhijānāti karmabhir na sa badhyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I desire the fruits of action. One who understands this about Me is not bound by karma.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The Divine acts without attachment or desire for results. Understanding and imitating this frees us from karmic bondage. Act like God acts - fully engaged, completely unattached.
shloks.strengthReflection: I imitate the Divine: acting fully while remaining unattached to results.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, teach me to act as You act - fully engaged yet completely free.

shloks.sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः। कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: evaṁ jñātvā kṛitaṁ karma pūrvair api mumukṣhubhiḥ kuru karmaiva tasmāt tvaṁ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Having known this, ancient seekers of liberation performed action. Therefore, perform action as the ancients did in ancient times.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Ancient liberated souls understood this and still performed action. Follow their example. Knowledge doesn't eliminate action but transforms it.
shloks.strengthReflection: I follow the example of ancient seekers: knowledge with action, not escapism.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, like the ancient seekers, I embrace enlightened action.

shloks.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः। तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्॥
shloks.transliteration: kiṁ karma kim akarmeti kavayo 'py atra mohitāḥ tat te karma pravakṣhyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣhyase 'śhubhāt
shloks.simpleMeaning: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused. I shall teach you about action, knowing which you will be freed from evil.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Even wise people struggle to understand true action. Krishna promises to clarify. This understanding leads to liberation from negativity.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek deep understanding of action that even confuses the wise.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, teach me the secret of action that liberates.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः॥
shloks.transliteration: karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṁ boddhavyaṁ cha vikarmaṇaḥ akarmaṇaśh cha boddhavyaṁ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: One must understand proper action, forbidden action, and inaction. The path of action is profound.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Three categories: action, wrong action, and non-action. Each must be understood. The nature of karma is subtle and complex.
shloks.strengthReflection: I study the subtleties of action carefully, not assuming I understand.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, guide me through the profound complexities of action and karma.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्॥
shloks.transliteration: karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśhyed akarmaṇi cha karma yaḥ sa buddhimān manuṣhyeṣhu sa yuktaḥ kṛitsna-karma-kṛit
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is wise among humans. Such a person is a yogi who has accomplished all action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The wise see non-action within action (acting without ego attachment) and action within inaction (lazy avoidance is itself a karma). This paradoxical vision is true wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see beyond surface appearances to the deeper truth of action and inaction.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, grant me the vision to see inaction in action and action in inaction.

shloks.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः॥
shloks.transliteration: yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṁ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: One whose every undertaking is free from desire and selfish motive, whose actions are burned in the fire of knowledge — the wise call such a person learned.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The true sage acts without selfish desire. Knowledge has burned away karmic bonds. Such a person is truly learned.
shloks.strengthReflection: I burn away selfish motives through knowledge, purifying my actions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let the fire of knowledge burn away all selfish desires in my actions.

shloks.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः। कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः॥
shloks.transliteration: tyaktvā karma-phalāsaṅgaṁ nitya-tṛipto nirāśhrayaḥ karmaṇy abhipravṛitto 'pi naiva kiñchit karoti saḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of action, ever satisfied, depending on nothing — though engaged in action, such a person does nothing at all.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Complete detachment from results, self-sufficient, needing nothing. Such a person acts yet creates no karma. Action without karmic consequence - this is the goal.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work toward that state where action no longer binds me.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, bring me to that freedom where I act yet remain untouched.

shloks.sanskrit: निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः। शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्॥
shloks.transliteration: nirāśhīr yata-chittātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ śhārīraṁ kevalaṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣham
shloks.simpleMeaning: Free from desire, with mind and body controlled, having relinquished all possessions, performing only bodily action — such a person incurs no sin.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Without desire, with controlled mind, possessing nothing, doing only what the body requires - such action brings no karmic consequence.
shloks.strengthReflection: I simplify my desires and possessions, reducing karmic entanglement.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, free me from desire and possession. Let me act in purity.

shloks.sanskrit: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः। समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: yadṛichchhā-lābha-santuṣhṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ samaḥ siddhāv asiddhau cha kṛitvāpi na nibadhyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Content with whatever comes unsought, beyond dualities, free from envy, equal in success and failure — even while acting, such a person is not bound.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Satisfied with what comes naturally, beyond opposites, without envy, equal in success and failure - this person acts without bondage. The secret is inner attitude.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate contentment, equanimity, and freedom from envy.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, make me content with what You provide, equal in all outcomes.

shloks.sanskrit: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः। यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते॥
shloks.transliteration: gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-chetasaḥ yajñāyācharataḥ karma samagraṁ pravilīyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: For one free from attachment, liberated, with mind established in knowledge, acting only as sacrifice — all karma completely dissolves.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When attachment is gone, freedom achieved, mind rooted in knowledge, action becomes sacrifice. In this state, all karma dissolves completely.
shloks.strengthReflection: I transform my actions into sacrifice, dissolving karmic residue.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let all my actions become sacrifice to You, dissolving all karma.

shloks.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना॥
shloks.transliteration: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā
shloks.simpleMeaning: The offering is Brahman, the oblation is Brahman, offered by Brahman into the fire of Brahman. Brahman shall be attained by one absorbed in Brahman through action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Everything is Brahman - the giver, the giving, the gift, the receiver. When we see this unity, action becomes meditation, and we merge with the Absolute.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see the Divine in action itself - giver, gift, and receiver are One.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Brahman, I see You everywhere - in me, my offering, and all existence.

shloks.sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते। ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति॥
shloks.transliteration: daivam evāpare yajñaṁ yoginaḥ paryupāsate brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṁ yajñenaivopajuhvati
shloks.simpleMeaning: Some yogis worship the gods through various sacrifices. Others offer the self as sacrifice into the fire of Brahman.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Different spiritual practitioners have different approaches. Some worship gods ritually; others offer the self directly into the Absolute. Multiple valid paths exist.
shloks.strengthReflection: I respect various spiritual approaches while following my own authentic path.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, I offer myself as sacrifice into the fire of Your being.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति। शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye sanyamāgniṣhu juhvati śhabdādīn viṣhayān anya indriyāgniṣhu juhvati
shloks.simpleMeaning: Some offer the senses such as hearing into the fire of self-control. Others offer sense objects such as sound into the fire of the senses.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Some sacrifice by restraining their senses; others sacrifice by consciously experiencing sense objects. Both approaches can be spiritual when done with awareness.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice both restraint and conscious engagement as forms of spiritual discipline.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, accept my sacrifices whether through restraint or mindful experience.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे। आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते॥
shloks.transliteration: sarvāṇīndriya-karmāṇi prāṇa-karmāṇi chāpare ātma-sanyama-yogāgnau juhvati jñāna-dīpite
shloks.simpleMeaning: Others offer all sense activities and vital functions into the fire of the yoga of self-control, kindled by knowledge.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Some offer all their sensory and vital activities into the fire of self-discipline lit by wisdom. Everything becomes part of the spiritual sacrifice.
shloks.strengthReflection: I transform all my activities into spiritual practice through awareness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let every breath and action become an offering to You.

shloks.sanskrit: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे। स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः॥
shloks.transliteration: dravya-yajñās tapo-yajñā yoga-yajñās tathāpare svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāś cha yatayaḥ sanśhita-vratāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Some offer material possessions; others offer austerities, yoga practice, study, or knowledge as sacrifices — all with strict vows.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Various forms of sacrifice: wealth, austerity, yoga, self-study, knowledge. All valid paths when done with sincere commitment and discipline.
shloks.strengthReflection: I choose my form of sacrifice and commit to it with discipline.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, accept whatever sacrifice I can offer with sincerity.

shloks.sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे। प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः॥
shloks.transliteration: apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe 'pānaṁ tathāpare prāṇāpāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Some offer the outgoing breath into the incoming, and the incoming into the outgoing, mastering both through pranayama.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Breath control (pranayama) is itself a sacrifice. Regulating the life force through breath mastery is a powerful spiritual practice.
shloks.strengthReflection: I use breath awareness as a doorway to spiritual practice.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, with each breath I offer my life force to You.

shloks.sanskrit: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति। सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः॥
shloks.transliteration: apare niyatāhārāḥ prāṇān prāṇeṣhu juhvati sarve 'py ete yajña-vido yajña-kṣhapita-kalmaṣhāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Others regulate their diet and offer the life breath into the life breath itself. All these know the meaning of sacrifice and through sacrifice destroy their sins.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Dietary discipline is also sacrifice. All who understand sacrifice purify themselves through it, destroying sins and karmic residues.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice mindful eating as a form of spiritual discipline.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let my eating become a sacred offering, purifying my body and soul.

shloks.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्। नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम॥
shloks.transliteration: yajña-śhiṣhṭāmṛita-bhujo yānti brahma sanātanam nāyaṁ loko 'sty ayajñasya kuto 'nyaḥ kuru-sattama
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those who eat the nectar remnants of sacrifice attain eternal Brahman. Without sacrifice, one cannot be happy even in this world — what then of the next, O best of the Kurus?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sacrifice brings blessings both here and hereafter. Without some form of sacrifice, even worldly happiness is impossible. Giving leads to receiving.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice sacrifice knowing it brings blessings in this life and beyond.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me live a life of offering, receiving Your sacred remnants.

shloks.sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे। कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे॥
shloks.transliteration: evaṁ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe karma-jān viddhi tān sarvān evaṁ jñātvā vimokṣhyase
shloks.simpleMeaning: Thus many kinds of sacrifices are described in the Vedas. Know them all to be born of action. Knowing this, you shall be liberated.
shloks.practicalExplanation: All sacrifices are forms of action. Understanding this unified nature of spiritual practice leads to liberation. Don't be confused by variety - see the unity within.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see unity in various spiritual practices, all leading to liberation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, help me understand the essence behind all forms of sacrifice.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप। सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: śhreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ parantapa sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: O scorcher of foes, the sacrifice of knowledge is superior to material sacrifice. All actions culminate in knowledge, O Partha.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Knowledge sacrifice exceeds material sacrifice. All action ultimately finds completion in wisdom. The goal of all practice is understanding.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek knowledge above all, knowing it is the completion of all action.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, lead all my actions toward the culmination of true knowledge.

shloks.sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः॥
shloks.transliteration: tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśhnena sevayā upadekṣhyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśhinaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Learn this by humble submission, inquiry, and service. The wise who have seen the truth will impart knowledge to you.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Seek wisdom through humility, questioning, and service to the wise. Those who have realized truth can transmit it to sincere students.
shloks.strengthReflection: I approach teachers with humility, inquiry, and service.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, send me teachers who have seen truth. Make me a worthy student.

shloks.sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव। येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि॥
shloks.transliteration: yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava yena bhūtāny aśheṣheṇa drakṣhyasy ātmany atho mayi
shloks.simpleMeaning: Having known this, O Pandava, you will not fall into delusion again. By this knowledge, you will see all beings in yourself and in Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: True knowledge ends delusion permanently. You will see all beings within yourself and within God. This is the vision of unity that liberates.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek knowledge that ends delusion and reveals unity with all beings.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me knowledge that shows all beings in myself and You.

shloks.sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः। सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि॥
shloks.transliteration: api ched asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛittamaḥ sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛijinaṁ santariṣhyasi
shloks.simpleMeaning: Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you will cross over all sin by the boat of knowledge.
shloks.practicalExplanation: No matter how much sin you've accumulated, knowledge can carry you across. The past doesn't define you - transformation through wisdom is always possible.
shloks.strengthReflection: No matter my past mistakes, knowledge can liberate me. I am not defined by my sins.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, carry me across the ocean of sin on the boat of Your knowledge.

shloks.sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन। ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा॥
shloks.transliteration: yathaidhānsi samiddho 'gnir bhasma-sāt kurute 'rjuna jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasma-sāt kurute tathā
shloks.simpleMeaning: As a blazing fire reduces wood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all karma to ashes.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Knowledge burns karma like fire burns wood. Complete destruction of karmic bondage through the fire of wisdom. This is the liberating power of true understanding.
shloks.strengthReflection: I kindle the fire of knowledge to burn away all karmic accumulation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, let the fire of Your knowledge burn away all my karma.

shloks.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति॥
shloks.transliteration: na hi jñānena sadṛiśhaṁ pavitram iha vidyate tat svayaṁ yoga-sansiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati
shloks.simpleMeaning: Truly, there is nothing as purifying as knowledge in this world. One who has become perfected in yoga finds this knowledge within oneself in due time.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Nothing purifies like knowledge. The one perfected in yoga naturally discovers this wisdom within. Time and practice reveal what is already present.
shloks.strengthReflection: I trust that with practice, inner knowledge will naturally emerge.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: Lord, in Your time, reveal the knowledge already present within me.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
shloks.transliteration: śhraddhāvān labhate jñānaṁ tat-paraḥ sanyatendriyaḥ jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śhāntim achireṇādhigachchhati
