shloks.sanskrit: मा ते व्यथा मा च विमूढभावो दृष्ट्वा रूपं घोरमीदृङ्ममेदम्। व्यपेतभीः प्रीतमनाः पुनस्त्वं तदेव मे रूपमिदं प्रपश्य॥
shloks.transliteration: mā te vyathā mā cha vimūḍha-bhāvo dṛiṣhṭvā rūpaṁ ghoram īdṛiṅ mamedam vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ punas tvaṁ tad eva me rūpam idaṁ prapaśhya
shloks.simpleMeaning: Do not be distressed or bewildered by seeing this terrible form of Mine. Free from fear and with a glad heart, behold again My previous form.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna comforts Arjuna: don't be troubled or confused by the terrible vision. Let fear go and joy return. Now see My gentle form again. The Divine adjusts to what the devotee can receive. Terror yields to comfort when its purpose is served.
shloks.strengthReflection: Divine encounter can terrify, then comfort. Both are parts of complete revelation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I release my fear. Joyfully I receive Your gentle form.

shloks.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच। इत्यर्जुनं वासुदेवस्तथोक्त्वा स्वकं रूपं दर्शयामास भूयः। आश्वासयामास च भीतमेनं भूत्वा पुनः सौम्यवपुर्महात्मा॥
shloks.transliteration: sañjaya uvācha ity arjunaṁ vāsudevas tathoktvā svakaṁ rūpaṁ darśhayām āsa bhūyaḥ āśhvāsayām āsa cha bhītam enaṁ bhūtvā punaḥ saumya-vapur mahātmā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sanjaya said: Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Vasudeva displayed His own form again. The great-souled one, resuming His gentle form, comforted the frightened Arjuna.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sanjaya reports: Krishna showed His own (human) form again, resumed His gentle (saumya) appearance, and comforted the frightened Arjuna. The great teacher gives the ultimate vision, then reassures with familiar intimacy. Both are needed.
shloks.strengthReflection: Ultimate truth comforts after it overwhelms. The gentle form reassures.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O gentle Lord, thank You for returning to a form I can embrace without fear.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। दृष्ट्वेदं मानुषं रूपं तव सौम्यं जनार्दन। इदानीमस्मि संवृत्तः सचेताः प्रकृतिं गतः॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha dṛiṣhṭvedaṁ mānuṣhaṁ rūpaṁ tava saumyaṁ janārdana idānīm asmi sanvṛittaḥ sa-chetāḥ prakṛitiṁ gataḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O Janardana, seeing this gentle human form of Yours, I am now composed and have returned to my normal state of mind.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna expresses relief: seeing the gentle human form, he is composed again, returned to normal. The cosmic vision expanded awareness beyond normal limits; now normalcy returns. Both extraordinary revelation and normal relationship are needed.
shloks.strengthReflection: After cosmic expansion, returning to normal awareness is also grace.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I am composed again. Thank You for both the vision and the return.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। सुदुर्दर्शमिदं रूपं दृष्टवानसि यन्मम। देवा अप्यस्य रूपस्य नित्यं दर्शनकाङ्क्षिणः॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha su-durdarśham idaṁ rūpaṁ dṛiṣhṭavān asi yan mama devā apy asya rūpasya nityaṁ darśhana-kāṅkṣhiṇaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: This form of Mine that you have seen is very difficult to behold. Even the gods are ever longing to see this form.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna emphasizes the rarity of this vision: extremely difficult to see. Even gods constantly long for this sight yet cannot have it. Arjuna received what celestials desire. This confirms the special grace bestowed on the devoted seeker.
shloks.strengthReflection: What I seek through devotion, even gods long for. Devotion is powerful.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You showed me what even gods long to see. Infinite gratitude.

shloks.sanskrit: नाहं वेदैर्न तपसा न दानेन न चेज्यया। शक्य एवंविधो द्रष्टुं दृष्टवानसि मां यथा॥
shloks.transliteration: nāhaṁ vedair na tapasā na dānena na chejyayā śhakya evaṁ-vidho draṣhṭuṁ dṛiṣhṭavān asi māṁ yathā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Not by the Vedas, not by austerity, not by charity, not by sacrifice, can I be seen as you have seen Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Reiteration: no Vedas, no austerity, no charity, no sacrifice can produce this vision. What you saw, Arjuna, cannot be achieved through standard spiritual practices. Something beyond method is required — pure divine grace responding to pure devotion.
shloks.strengthReflection: Standard practices prepare but cannot guarantee divine vision. Grace is essential.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, no practice earned this. Your grace alone made it possible.

shloks.sanskrit: भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन। ज्ञातुं द्रष्टुं च तत्त्वेन प्रवेष्टुं च परन्तप॥
shloks.transliteration: bhaktyā tv ananyayā śhakya aham evaṁ-vidho 'rjuna jñātuṁ draṣhṭuṁ cha tattvena praveṣhṭuṁ cha parantapa
shloks.simpleMeaning: But by exclusive devotion, Arjuna, I can be known, seen in truth, and entered into, O scorcher of foes.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The key: exclusive devotion (ananya bhakti). By this alone can Krishna be truly known, truly seen, and truly entered into. Three levels: knowing (intellectual), seeing (visionary), entering (union). All three come through single-pointed devotion.
shloks.strengthReflection: Single-pointed devotion accomplishes what no other method can.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I offer exclusive devotion. Let me know, see, and enter into You.

shloks.sanskrit: मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः। निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव॥
shloks.transliteration: mat-karma-kṛin mat-paramo mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣhu yaḥ sa mām eti pāṇḍava
shloks.simpleMeaning: He who does work for Me, who takes Me as the supreme goal, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who is free from enmity toward all beings — he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The chapter's final verse gives the complete formula: (1) work for God, (2) take God as supreme goal, (3) be devoted to God, (4) be free from attachment, (5) be free from enmity toward all beings. These five qualities lead to divine union.
shloks.strengthReflection: Work for God, goal is God, devoted to God, unattached, friendly to all — this is the path.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I work for You, aim at You, love You, release attachments, and harm none.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। एवं सततयुक्ता ये भक्तास्त्वां पर्युपासते। ये चाप्यक्षरमव्यक्तं तेषां के योगवित्तमाः॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha evaṁ satata-yuktā ye bhaktās tvāṁ paryupāsate ye chāpy akṣharam avyaktaṁ teṣhāṁ ke yoga-vittamāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna asked: Between those devotees who worship You as the personal form, always connected, and those who worship the imperishable, unmanifest Brahman — which are better versed in yoga?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna asks the crucial question: is it better to worship a personal God or the impersonal absolute? This question touches the heart of spiritual practice. The answer will guide seekers in choosing their approach to the Divine.
shloks.strengthReflection: I consider which approach to the Divine suits my nature and capacity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, guide me to understand the best path for reaching You.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। मय्यावेश्य मनो ये मां नित्ययुक्ता उपासते। श्रद्धया परयोपेतास्ते मे युक्ततमा मताः॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha mayy āveśhya mano ye māṁ nitya-yuktā upāsate śhraddhayā parayopetās te me yuktatamā matāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: Those who fix their minds on Me and always worship Me with supreme faith — I consider them to be the most perfect in yoga.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna's clear answer: those who worship His personal form with mind focused, constant connection, and supreme faith are the most perfect yogis. This isn't dismissing other paths but recognizing that personal devotion is most accessible and effective for most seekers.
shloks.strengthReflection: Personal devotion with focused mind and supreme faith is the most direct path.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I fix my mind on You with utmost faith. Make me a perfect yogi.

shloks.sanskrit: ये त्वक्षरमनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं पर्युपासते। सर्वत्रगमचिन्त्यं च कूटस्थमचलं ध्रुवम्॥
shloks.transliteration: ye tv akṣharam anirdeśhyam avyaktaṁ paryupāsate sarvatra-gam achintyaṁ cha kūṭa-stham achalaṁ dhruvam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But those who worship the imperishable, indefinable, unmanifest, all-pervading, inconceivable, unchanging, immovable, and eternal...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Now Krishna describes the other path: worship of the formless absolute — imperishable, beyond description, unmanifest, everywhere, inconceivable, unchanging, immovable, eternal. These are valid attributes of the ultimate reality.
shloks.strengthReflection: The formless Divine is real — imperishable, unchanging, beyond description.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O formless Lord, I honor Your aspect beyond all conception.

shloks.sanskrit: सन्नियम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वत्र समबुद्धयः। ते प्राप्नुवन्ति मामेव सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥
shloks.transliteration: sanniyamyendriya-grāmaṁ sarvatra sama-buddhayaḥ te prāpnuvanti mām eva sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...controlling all their senses, equal-minded everywhere, engaged in the welfare of all beings — they also attain Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those worshipping the formless also reach God — if they control senses, are equanimous everywhere, and serve all beings' welfare. The formless path requires these disciplines. Both paths reach the same destination, but with different requirements.
shloks.strengthReflection: The formless path requires sense control, equanimity, and universal service.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, whether through form or formless, may I reach You through discipline.

shloks.sanskrit: क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम्। अव्यक्ता हि गतिर्दुःखं देहवद्भिरवाप्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: kleśho 'dhikataras teṣhām avyaktāsakta-chetasām avyaktā hi gatir duḥkhaṁ dehavadbhir avāpyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Greater is the difficulty for those whose minds are attached to the unmanifest, for the path of the unmanifest is hard for embodied beings to attain.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Here's the practical consideration: the formless path is harder for embodied beings. We have bodies and minds that naturally attach to forms. Pursuing the formless requires greater struggle (klesha). The personal path, while equally valid, is more natural for humans.
shloks.strengthReflection: I acknowledge my embodied nature and choose a path suited to it.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, guide me to the path suited to my nature. Help me avoid needless struggle.

shloks.sanskrit: ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्पराः। अनन्येनैव योगेन मां ध्यायन्त उपासते॥
shloks.transliteration: ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi sannyasya mat-parāḥ ananyenaiva yogena māṁ dhyāyanta upāsate
shloks.simpleMeaning: But those who worship Me, dedicating all actions to Me, regarding Me as the Supreme, meditating on Me with exclusive devotion...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna describes the personal devotee: all actions offered to Him, He is the supreme goal, meditation is on Him alone, devotion is exclusive. This verse begins the promise to such devotees.
shloks.strengthReflection: I dedicate all actions to God, make God my supreme goal, meditate exclusively on God.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, all my actions are Yours. You are my supreme goal. I meditate on You alone.

shloks.sanskrit: तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात्। भवामि नचिरात्पार्थ मय्यावेशितचेतसाम्॥
shloks.transliteration: teṣhām ahaṁ samuddhartā mṛityu-sansāra-sāgarāt bhavāmi na chirāt pārtha mayy āveśhita-chetasām
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...for those whose minds are absorbed in Me, I become their swift deliverer from the ocean of mortal existence, O Arjuna.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The magnificent promise: for those absorbed in Krishna, He Himself becomes the deliverer from the ocean of death and rebirth. And not eventually, but swiftly (na chirat). Personal devotion brings swift divine rescue.
shloks.strengthReflection: The Divine Himself rescues those absorbed in Him from the ocean of mortality.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, my mind is absorbed in You. Be my swift deliverer from all suffering.

shloks.sanskrit: मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय। निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः॥
shloks.transliteration: mayy eva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṁ niveśhaya nivasiṣhyasi mayy eva ata ūrdhvaṁ na sanśhayaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Fix your mind on Me alone, let your intellect dwell in Me. Thereafter you shall live in Me alone. Of this there is no doubt.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The instruction: put your mind (manas) on Me, place your intellect (buddhi) in Me. The result is living in God — not just after death but now and ever after. No doubt about this. Mind and intellect, both given to God, ensure divine dwelling.
shloks.strengthReflection: I give my mind and intellect to God and thereby live in God.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, my mind is on You, my intellect rests in You. Let me live in You always.

shloks.sanskrit: अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम्। अभ्यासयोगेन ततो मामिच्छाप्तुं धनञ्जय॥
shloks.transliteration: atha chittaṁ samādhātuṁ na śhaknoṣhi mayi sthiram abhyāsa-yogena tato mām ichchhāptuṁ dhanañjaya
shloks.simpleMeaning: If you cannot fix your mind steadily on Me, then seek to reach Me through the yoga of practice (repetition), O Arjuna.
shloks.practicalExplanation: If steady focus isn't possible (which is normal for most), then practice repeatedly. Abhyasa yoga — the discipline of repetition — develops the capacity that isn't natural at first. Keep trying; consistency builds capability.
shloks.strengthReflection: If steady focus is hard, I practice repeatedly. Consistency builds capability.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, when steady focus fails, I return again and again through practice.

shloks.sanskrit: अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव। मदर्थमपि कर्माणि कुर्वन्सिद्धिमवाप्स्यसि॥
shloks.transliteration: abhyāse 'py asamartho 'si mat-karma-paramo bhava mad-artham api karmāṇi kurvan siddhim avāpsyasi
shloks.simpleMeaning: If you are unable even to practice, be intent on acting for My sake. Even by performing actions for My sake, you shall attain perfection.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Even if formal practice is difficult, work for God's sake. Dedicate your actions to the Divine. Karma yoga becomes bhakti yoga when actions are offered to God. This is accessible to everyone — even busy people can work for God.
shloks.strengthReflection: Even when I can't practice formally, I dedicate my work to God.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I work for Your sake. Accept my actions as my offering.

shloks.sanskrit: अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः। सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं ततः कुरु यतात्मवान्॥
shloks.transliteration: athaitad apy aśhakto 'si kartuṁ mad-yogam āśhritaḥ sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ tataḥ kuru yatātmavān
shloks.simpleMeaning: If you are unable to do even this, then taking refuge in My yoga, renounce the fruits of all actions with self-control.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The final fallback: if even working for God seems impossible, simply renounce the fruits of your actions while taking refuge in divine yoga. Don't cling to results. This inner renunciation purifies even ordinary actions.
shloks.strengthReflection: At minimum, I can renounce the fruits of my actions and take refuge in God.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I release my attachment to results and take refuge in You.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते। ध्यानात्कर्मफलत्यागस्त्यागाच्छान्तिरनन्तरम्॥
shloks.transliteration: śhreyo hi jñānam abhyāsāj jñānād dhyānaṁ viśhiṣhyate dhyānāt karma-phala-tyāgas tyāgāch chhāntir anantaram
shloks.simpleMeaning: Knowledge is better than practice; meditation is better than knowledge; better than meditation is renunciation of the fruits of action — from such renunciation, peace immediately follows.
shloks.practicalExplanation: A hierarchy: practice < knowledge < meditation < renunciation of results. But the deeper meaning: if you can't do the higher, do the next lower. The highest achievable practice for you is best. And from renouncing results, peace immediately comes.
shloks.strengthReflection: I do the highest practice I'm capable of, knowing peace comes from releasing results.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me the capacity for higher practice, but always, I release attachment to results.

shloks.sanskrit: अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च। निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी॥
shloks.transliteration: adveṣhṭā sarva-bhūtānāṁ maitraḥ karuṇa eva cha nirmamo nirahankāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣhamī
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who has no hatred toward any being, who is friendly and compassionate, free from possessiveness and ego, balanced in pleasure and pain, forgiving...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Now Krishna describes the ideal devotee: no hatred, friendly to all, compassionate, without possessiveness, free from ego, balanced in joy and sorrow, forgiving. These are the marks of one who has genuinely absorbed divine teaching.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate: no hatred, friendliness, compassion, non-possessiveness, humility, balance, forgiveness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, shape me into such a devotee — friendly, forgiving, balanced, free.

shloks.sanskrit: सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः। मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥
shloks.transliteration: santuṣhṭaḥ satataṁ yogī yatātmā dṛiḍha-niśhchayaḥ mayy arpita-mano-buddhir yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...always content, self-controlled, of firm determination, with mind and intellect dedicated to Me — such a devotee is dear to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: More qualities: constant contentment, self-controlled, firmly determined, mind and intellect offered to God. Such a devotee is dear to Krishna. This phrase 'dear to Me' (priyah) is the refrain of this chapter — divine affection for the genuine devotee.
shloks.strengthReflection: I aspire to be: content, self-controlled, firm, with mind and intellect on God.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, make me dear to You by making me content, controlled, and dedicated.

shloks.sanskrit: यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः। हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैर्मुक्तो यः स च मे प्रियः॥
shloks.transliteration: yasmān nodvijate loko lokān nodvijate cha yaḥ harṣhāmarṣha-bhayodvegair mukto yaḥ sa cha me priyaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: One by whom the world is not agitated and who cannot be agitated by the world, who is free from joy, envy, fear, and anxiety — such a person is dear to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: A beautiful bidirectional peace: the devotee doesn't disturb others, and isn't disturbed by others. Free from excessive joy, jealousy, fear, and anxious agitation. This equilibrium makes one dear to Krishna.
shloks.strengthReflection: I neither disturb the world nor am disturbed by it — balanced in all emotions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me this bidirectional peace. Let me be a non-disturbing presence.

shloks.sanskrit: अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः। सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥
shloks.transliteration: anapekṣhaḥ śhuchir dakṣha udāsīno gata-vyathaḥ sarvārambha-parityāgī yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who is without expectations, pure, skillful, impartial, free from anxiety, renouncing all selfish undertakings — such a devotee is dear to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: More qualities: no expectations from others, inner and outer purity, capable and efficient, impartial, free from anxiety, renouncing self-serving initiatives. This devotee is free from the neediness that causes suffering.
shloks.strengthReflection: I release expectations, cultivate purity, develop skill, remain impartial, renounce selfish projects.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from expectations and anxiety. Make me pure and skillful.

shloks.sanskrit: यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति। शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्तिमान्यः स मे प्रियः॥
shloks.transliteration: yo na hṛiṣhyati na dveṣhṭi na śhochati na kāṅkṣhati śhubhāśhubha-parityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who neither rejoices nor hates, neither grieves nor desires, renouncing both good and bad, full of devotion — such a person is dear to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Equanimity in four directions: no excessive rejoicing, no hatred, no grieving, no craving. Renouncing attachment to both good and bad outcomes. Full of devotion. This is the balanced devotee dear to Krishna.
shloks.strengthReflection: Neither excessive joy nor hatred, grief nor craving — I stand balanced in devotion.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, balance me in all circumstances. Let me be full of devotion alone.

shloks.sanskrit: समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः। शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः॥
shloks.transliteration: samaḥ śhatrau cha mitre cha tathā mānāpamānayoḥ śhītoṣhṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣhu samaḥ saṅga-vivarjitaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Equal toward friend and foe, in honor and dishonor, in heat and cold, in pleasure and pain, free from attachment...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Equanimity across opposites: friend and enemy, honor and disgrace, heat and cold, pleasure and pain. Free from attachment to any. This describes the mind that has truly transcended the pairs of opposites.
shloks.strengthReflection: I treat friend and foe equally, remain balanced in all dualities.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from attachment to pairs of opposites. Make me truly equal.

shloks.sanskrit: तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येन केनचित्। अनिकेतः स्थिरमतिर्भक्तिमान्मे प्रियो नरः॥
shloks.transliteration: tulya-nindā-stutir maunī santuṣhṭo yena kenachit aniketaḥ sthira-matir bhaktimān me priyo naraḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...one who is equal in blame and praise, silent, content with whatever comes, homeless, steady-minded, full of devotion — such a person is dear to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Equal in criticism and praise, inclined to silence, content with whatever comes, not attached to dwelling, steady-minded, full of devotion. These qualities describe true spiritual freedom — nothing can shake such a devotee.
shloks.strengthReflection: Criticism and praise are equal to me. I am content with whatever comes.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, steady my mind, content my heart, fill me with devotion.

shloks.sanskrit: ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते। श्रद्दधाना मत्परमा भक्तास्तेऽतीव मे प्रियाः॥
shloks.transliteration: ye tu dharmyāmṛitam idaṁ yathoktaṁ paryupāsate śhraddadhānā mat-paramā bhaktās te 'tīva me priyāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: But those who follow this immortal dharma as I have declared, with faith, regarding Me as the Supreme — such devoted ones are exceedingly dear to Me.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The chapter concludes: those who follow this immortal teaching with faith, taking Krishna as supreme, are exceedingly (ativa) dear. Not just dear — supremely dear. Faith and practice of these teachings bring the devotee into divine favor.
shloks.strengthReflection: Following these teachings with faith and supreme devotion makes me dear to God.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I follow this immortal teaching with faith. You are my Supreme. Let me be dear to You.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव क्षेत्रं क्षेत्रज्ञमेव च। एतद्वेदितुमिच्छामि ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं च केशव॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha prakṛitiṁ puruṣhaṁ chaiva kṣhetraṁ kṣhetra-jñam eva cha etad veditum ichchhāmi jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ cha keśhava
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O Keshava, I wish to know about Prakriti (Nature) and Purusha (the Soul), the field and the knower of the field, knowledge and the object of knowledge.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna asks fundamental questions about the relationship between matter and spirit, body and soul, wisdom and its goal. This chapter will reveal the deepest understanding of who we truly are beyond the body.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek to understand the difference between my body (the field) and my true self (the knower).
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me the distinction between matter and spirit, so I may know my true nature.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते। एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha idaṁ śharīraṁ kaunteya kṣhetram ity abhidhīyate etad yo vetti taṁ prāhuḥ kṣhetra-jña iti tad-vidaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: This body, O son of Kunti, is called the field. One who knows this is called the knower of the field by those who know.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna defines the key terms: the body is the field (kshetra) — the arena where experiences occur. The soul who witnesses and knows the body is the knower (kshetrajna). Recognizing this distinction is the beginning of wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: My body is the field of action; I am the conscious witness who knows it.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me realize that I am not this body but the eternal knower within.

shloks.sanskrit: क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत। क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्ज्ञानं यत्तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम॥
shloks.transliteration: kṣhetra-jñaṁ chāpi māṁ viddhi sarva-kṣhetreṣhu bhārata kṣhetra-kṣhetra-jñayor jñānaṁ yat taj jñānaṁ mataṁ mama
shloks.simpleMeaning: Know Me also as the knower in all fields, O Bharata. The knowledge of both the field and the knower — that I consider true knowledge.
shloks.practicalExplanation: A profound revelation: Krishna is the supreme knower present in all bodies. The individual soul knows its own body; God knows all bodies. True knowledge is understanding both the field (matter) and its knower (spirit).
shloks.strengthReflection: God is the supreme knower present within all beings, including me.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the supreme knower in all fields. Help me know You within my heart.

shloks.sanskrit: तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक्च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत्। स च यो यत्प्रभावश्च तत्समासेन मे शृणु॥
shloks.transliteration: tat kṣhetraṁ yach cha yādṛik cha yad-vikāri yataśh cha yat sa cha yo yat-prabhāvaśh cha tat samāsena me śhṛiṇu
shloks.simpleMeaning: Hear from Me briefly what that field is, what its nature is, what its modifications are, from what it arises, who the knower is, and what his powers are.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna promises to explain: (1) what the field is, (2) its nature, (3) its changes, (4) its origin, (5) who the knower is, and (6) the knower's powers. These six aspects cover complete knowledge of matter and spirit.
shloks.strengthReflection: Complete knowledge includes understanding both the field and the knower fully.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, reveal to me the complete knowledge of body and soul.

shloks.sanskrit: ऋषिभिर्बहुधा गीतं छन्दोभिर्विविधैः पृथक्। ब्रह्मसूत्रपदैश्चैव हेतुमद्भिर्विनिश्चितैः॥
shloks.transliteration: ṛiṣhibhir bahudhā gītaṁ chhandobhir vividhaiḥ pṛithak brahma-sūtra-padaiśh chaiva hetumadbhir viniśhchitaiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: This knowledge has been sung by sages in various ways, in various Vedic hymns, and especially in the well-reasoned conclusions of the Brahma Sutras.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna acknowledges that many sages have taught this knowledge through Vedic hymns and philosophical texts like the Brahma Sutras. The Gita synthesizes this wisdom for practical application.
shloks.strengthReflection: The wisdom of the Gita is supported by the entire tradition of spiritual knowledge.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I receive this timeless wisdom taught by all sages through You.

shloks.sanskrit: महाभूतान्यहंकारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च। इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च पञ्च चेन्द्रियगोचराः॥
shloks.transliteration: mahā-bhūtāny ahaṅkāro buddhir avyaktam eva cha indriyāṇi daśhaikaṁ cha pañcha chendriya-gocharāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The five great elements, ego, intellect, the unmanifest, the ten senses and one (mind), and the five objects of the senses...
shloks.practicalExplanation: The field consists of: five elements (earth, water, fire, air, ether), ego (ahamkara), intellect (buddhi), unmanifest matter, eleven senses (five knowing, five working, plus mind), and five sense objects (sound, touch, form, taste, smell).
shloks.strengthReflection: I understand that my body-mind complex is made of these material elements.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me see these components clearly so I may transcend identification with them.

shloks.sanskrit: इच्छा द्वेषः सुखं दुःखं सङ्घातश्चेतना धृतिः। एतत्क्षेत्रं समासेन सविकारमुदाहृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: ichchhā dveṣhaḥ sukhaṁ duḥkhaṁ saṅghātaśh chetanā dhṛitiḥ etat kṣhetraṁ samāsena sa-vikāram udāhṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...desire, aversion, pleasure, pain, the aggregate body, consciousness, and fortitude — this is the field described briefly with its modifications.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The field also includes psychological aspects: desire, aversion, pleasure, pain, the physical body, consciousness (reflected in the body), and determination. All these experiences occur in the field — we are the witness.
shloks.strengthReflection: Even my desires, aversions, pleasures, and pains belong to the field — I am the witness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me witness all experiences without being bound by identification.

shloks.sanskrit: अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम्। आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः॥
shloks.transliteration: amānitvam adambhitvam ahiṁsā kṣhāntir ārjavam āchāryopāsanaṁ śhauchaṁ sthairyam ātma-vinigrahaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Humility, unpretentiousness, non-violence, forgiveness, straightforwardness, service to the teacher, purity, steadiness, self-control...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Now Krishna lists qualities that constitute true knowledge. First: humility, sincerity, non-violence, patience, honesty, devotion to the teacher, inner and outer purity, stability, and self-mastery. These virtues lead to wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate humility, non-violence, patience, honesty, purity, and self-control.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, develop these foundational virtues within me.

shloks.sanskrit: इन्द्रियार्थेषु वैराग्यमनहंकार एव च। जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम्॥
shloks.transliteration: indriyārtheṣhu vairāgyam anahaṅkāra eva cha janma-mṛityu-jarā-vyādhi-duḥkha-doṣhānudarśhanam
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...detachment from sense objects, absence of ego, perceiving the evils of birth, death, old age, disease, and suffering...
shloks.practicalExplanation: True knowledge includes: detachment from sense pleasures, freedom from ego, and clear perception of the suffering inherent in birth, death, aging, and disease. Seeing life's inevitable pains motivates spiritual seeking.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see clearly that birth, death, aging, and disease are inevitable sufferings in material existence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me detachment and freedom from ego through clear seeing.

shloks.sanskrit: असक्तिरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु। नित्यं च समचित्तत्वमिष्टानिष्टोपपत्तिषु॥
shloks.transliteration: asaktir anabhiṣhvaṅgaḥ putra-dāra-gṛihādiṣhu nityaṁ cha sama-chittatvam iṣhṭāniṣhṭopapattiṣhu
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...non-attachment, non-identification with son, wife, home and the like, constant equanimity amid pleasant and unpleasant events...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Knowledge includes non-attachment to family and possessions — not abandoning duties but holding lightly. Also, maintaining equanimity when pleasant or unpleasant events occur. This balance indicates spiritual maturity.
shloks.strengthReflection: I love without clutching and remain balanced in both pleasant and unpleasant situations.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me loving detachment and constant equanimity.

shloks.sanskrit: मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्तिरव्यभिचारिणी। विविक्तदेशसेवित्वमरतिर्जनसंसदि॥
shloks.transliteration: mayi chānanya-yogena bhaktir avyabhichāriṇī vivikta-deśha-sevitvam aratir jana-saṁsadi
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...unwavering devotion to Me through exclusive yoga, preference for solitude, distaste for crowds...
shloks.practicalExplanation: True knowledge includes exclusive devotion to God, preference for quiet places conducive to contemplation, and natural distaste for worldly gatherings. Solitude supports inner focus and spiritual growth.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate exclusive devotion to God and seek solitude for spiritual growth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my devotion to You be unwavering and exclusive.

shloks.sanskrit: अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम्। एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोऽन्यथा॥
shloks.transliteration: adhyātma-jñāna-nityatvaṁ tattva-jñānārtha-darśhanam etaj jñānam iti proktam ajñānaṁ yad ato 'nyathā
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...constancy in self-knowledge, perception of the purpose of true knowledge — this is declared to be knowledge. What is contrary to this is ignorance.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The list concludes: constant engagement in self-knowledge and understanding wisdom's goal (liberation). All these qualities together constitute true knowledge (jnana); their absence is ignorance (ajnana).
shloks.strengthReflection: I am constantly engaged in self-knowledge, understanding that this leads to liberation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, establish me in true knowledge and remove all ignorance.

shloks.sanskrit: ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वामृतमश्नुते। अनादिमत्परं ब्रह्म न सत्तन्नासदुच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: jñeyaṁ yat tat pravakṣhyāmi yaj jñātvāmṛitam aśhnute anādi mat-paraṁ brahma na sat tan nāsad uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: I shall now describe that which is to be known, knowing which one attains immortality — the beginningless Supreme Brahman, said to be neither being nor non-being.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Now Krishna describes the object of knowledge: Brahman — beginningless, supreme, beyond conventional categories of existence and non-existence. Knowing This brings immortality. Brahman transcends all dualities.
shloks.strengthReflection: The goal of knowledge is the Supreme Brahman, beyond all categories.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, reveal Yourself to me — the supreme reality beyond being and non-being.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वतः पाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम्। सर्वतः श्रुतिमल्लोके सर्वमावृत्य तिष्ठति॥
shloks.transliteration: sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādaṁ tat sarvato 'kṣhi-śhiro-mukham sarvataḥ śhrutimal loke sarvam āvṛitya tiṣhṭhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: With hands and feet everywhere, eyes, heads, and faces everywhere, with ears everywhere — That exists pervading all.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Brahman has hands, feet, eyes, heads, faces, and ears everywhere — not literally, but by being present in all beings. God sees through all eyes, acts through all hands, hears through all ears. Divine omnipresence is described poetically.
shloks.strengthReflection: God is present everywhere, seeing, acting, and hearing through all beings.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are in all beings. May I see You everywhere.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम्। असक्तं सर्वभृच्चैव निर्गुणं गुणभोक्तृ च॥
shloks.transliteration: sarvendriya-guṇābhāsaṁ sarvendriya-vivarjitam asaktaṁ sarva-bhṛich chaiva nirguṇaṁ guṇa-bhoktṛi cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Reflecting the functions of all senses yet without senses, unattached yet supporting all, free from the gunas yet experiencing them.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Brahman illumines all sense activities without possessing senses, supports everything without attachment, is beyond the three gunas yet experiences them through beings. This describes God's transcendent immanence — present yet beyond.
shloks.strengthReflection: God supports all without attachment, transcends all qualities yet experiences them.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, though beyond all, You are the support and experiencer within all.

shloks.sanskrit: बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च। सूक्ष्मत्वात्तदविज्ञेयं दूरस्थं चान्तिके च तत्॥
shloks.transliteration: bahir antaśh cha bhūtānām acharaṁ charam eva cha sūkṣhmatvāt tad avijñeyaṁ dūra-sthaṁ chāntike cha tat
shloks.simpleMeaning: Outside and inside all beings, unmoving yet moving, unknowable due to subtlety, far away and yet near.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Brahman is outside all beings as the cosmic reality and inside as the inner self. Unmoving as the absolute, yet appearing to move in manifestations. So subtle as to be unknowable to the senses. Far away (transcendent) yet near (immanent).
shloks.strengthReflection: God is both far and near, outside and inside, still and moving.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, though You seem far, You are nearer than my own heart.

shloks.sanskrit: अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम्। भूतभर्तृ च तज्ज्ञेयं ग्रसिष्णु प्रभविष्णु च॥
shloks.transliteration: avibhaktaṁ cha bhūteṣhu vibhaktam iva cha sthitam bhūta-bhartṛi cha taj jñeyaṁ grasiṣhṇu prabhaviṣhṇu cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Undivided, yet seeming divided among beings; the sustainer, devourer, and creator of all beings — know That as the knowable.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Though Brahman is one and undivided, it appears divided among beings like space appears divided in pots. Brahman sustains all (as Vishnu), dissolves all (as Shiva), and creates all (as Brahma). This is what is to be known.
shloks.strengthReflection: One God appears as many, sustaining, dissolving, and creating all beings.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are one yet appear as many. You are creator, sustainer, and dissolver.

shloks.sanskrit: ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते। ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानगम्यं हृदि सर्वस्य विष्ठितम्॥
shloks.transliteration: jyotiṣhām api taj jyotis tamasaḥ param uchyate jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ jñāna-gamyaṁ hṛidi sarvasya viṣhṭhitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: That is the light of all lights, said to be beyond darkness. It is knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Brahman is the light illuminating all lights — the sun borrows its brilliance from That. Beyond all darkness of ignorance. It is knowledge itself, what is to be known, and the destination reached through knowledge. Present in every heart.
shloks.strengthReflection: The Divine light is in my heart, the knowledge, the known, and the goal.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the light of my heart. Illuminate my darkness with Your presence.

shloks.sanskrit: इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः। मद्भक्त एतद्विज्ञाय मद्भावायोपपद्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: iti kṣhetraṁ tathā jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ choktaṁ samāsataḥ mad-bhakta etad vijñāya mad-bhāvāyopapadyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Thus the field, knowledge, and the object of knowledge have been briefly described. My devotee, understanding this, attains My nature.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna summarizes: the field (body-mind), knowledge (virtues and understanding), and the knowable (Brahman) have been described. The devotee who understands this attains Krishna's own nature — divine consciousness.
shloks.strengthReflection: Understanding the field, knowledge, and the knowable, I attain divine nature.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, through understanding these truths, may I attain Your divine nature.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव विद्ध्यनादी उभावपि। विकारांश्च गुणांश्चैव विद्धि प्रकृतिसंभवान्॥
shloks.transliteration: prakṛitiṁ puruṣhaṁ chaiva viddhy anādī ubhāv api vikārāṁśh cha guṇāṁśh chaiva viddhi prakṛiti-sambhavān
shloks.simpleMeaning: Know that both Prakriti (Nature) and Purusha (Soul) are beginningless. Know also that modifications and qualities arise from Prakriti.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Both matter (Prakriti) and spirit (Purusha) are beginningless — eternally existing. All modifications (transformations of matter) and qualities (sattva, rajas, tamas) arise from Prakriti, not from the pure soul.
shloks.strengthReflection: Matter and spirit are both eternal; changes and qualities belong to matter, not my true self.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me understand that all changes belong to nature, while I am eternal spirit.

shloks.sanskrit: कार्यकारणकर्तृत्वे हेतुः प्रकृतिरुच्यते। पुरुषः सुखदुःखानां भोक्तृत्वे हेतुरुच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: kārya-kāraṇa-kartṛitve hetuḥ prakṛitir uchyate puruṣhaḥ sukha-duḥkhānāṁ bhoktṛitve hetur uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Prakriti is said to be the cause of the body, senses, and their functions. The Purusha is said to be the cause of experiencing pleasure and pain.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Prakriti (nature/matter) causes the body and its activities (objective reality). Purusha (soul) causes the experience of pleasure and pain (subjective consciousness). Body acts; soul experiences. This is the division of roles.
shloks.strengthReflection: My body acts through nature; I experience through consciousness. Each has its role.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me understand that action belongs to nature while experience belongs to consciousness.

shloks.sanskrit: पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान्गुणान्। कारणं गुणसङ्गोऽस्य सदसद्योनिजन्मसु॥
shloks.transliteration: puruṣhaḥ prakṛiti-stho hi bhuṅkte prakṛiti-jān guṇān kāraṇaṁ guṇa-saṅgo 'sya sad-asad-yoni-janmasu
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Purusha, seated in Prakriti, experiences the qualities born of Prakriti. Attachment to these qualities is the cause of birth in good and evil wombs.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When the soul identifies with the body, it experiences nature's qualities as its own. This attachment to qualities causes rebirth — in good or evil circumstances based on karma. Identification is the root of bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: My identification with nature's qualities causes my bondage and rebirth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from identification with nature's qualities so I may be liberated.

shloks.sanskrit: उपद्रष्टानुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः। परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन्पुरुषः परः॥
shloks.transliteration: upadraṣhṭānumantā cha bhartā bhoktā maheśhvaraḥ paramātmeti chāpy ukto dehe 'smin puruṣhaḥ paraḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the witness, the permitter, the supporter, the experiencer, the Great Lord, and the Supreme Self.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Within the body dwells the Supreme Soul with many functions: witness (observing all), permitter (allowing actions), supporter (sustaining existence), experiencer (conscious presence), Great Lord (supreme controller), and Supreme Self (beyond individual ego).
shloks.strengthReflection: The Supreme Soul within me witnesses, permits, supports, experiences, and rules.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord within, You are the witness, supporter, and ruler of my being.

shloks.sanskrit: य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह। सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते॥
shloks.transliteration: ya evaṁ vetti puruṣhaṁ prakṛitiṁ cha guṇaiḥ saha sarvathā vartamāno 'pi na sa bhūyo 'bhijāyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who thus knows the Purusha and Prakriti along with the gunas, however situated, is never born again.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Whoever truly understands the soul, nature, and the three qualities — regardless of their current life situation — is freed from rebirth. Knowledge itself liberates. The understanding that 'I am not the body or its changes' ends bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: Understanding soul and nature with the gunas liberates me from rebirth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me this liberating knowledge that frees from all rebirth.

shloks.sanskrit: ध्यानेनात्मनि पश्यन्ति केचिदात्मानमात्मना। अन्ये साङ्ख्येन योगेन कर्मयोगेन चापरे॥
shloks.transliteration: dhyānenātmani paśhyanti kechid ātmānam ātmanā anye sāṅkhyena yogena karma-yogena chāpare
shloks.simpleMeaning: Some perceive the Self within through meditation; others through the yoga of knowledge; still others through the yoga of action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Different paths lead to self-realization: some attain through meditation (dhyana yoga), others through philosophical knowledge (sankhya/jnana yoga), others through selfless action (karma yoga). The path varies; the goal is one.
shloks.strengthReflection: I can realize the Self through meditation, knowledge, or selfless action.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, guide me to the path suited to my nature that leads to self-realization.

shloks.sanskrit: अन्ये त्वेवमजानन्तः श्रुत्वान्येभ्य उपासते। तेऽपि चातितरन्त्येव मृत्युं श्रुतिपरायणाः॥
shloks.transliteration: anye tv evam ajānantaḥ śhrutvānyebhya upāsate te 'pi chātitaranty eva mṛityuṁ śhruti-parāyaṇāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Others, not knowing these paths, worship as they have heard from others. They too cross beyond death, devoted to what they have heard.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Even those who don't understand philosophical paths can transcend death by faithfully following teachings they've heard from wise teachers. Faith and dedicated practice of received wisdom also leads to liberation.
shloks.strengthReflection: Even without understanding all paths, I can transcend through faithful practice.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I follow what I have heard with faith. Lead me beyond death.

shloks.sanskrit: यावत्सञ्जायते किञ्चित्सत्त्वं स्थावरजङ्गमम्। क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञसंयोगात्तद्विद्धि भरतर्षभ॥
shloks.transliteration: yāvat sañjāyate kiñchit sattvaṁ sthāvara-jaṅgamam kṣhetra-kṣhetrajña-saṁyogāt tad viddhi bharatarṣhabha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Whatever being is born, moving or unmoving, know that it arises from the union of the field and the knower of the field, O best of the Bharatas.
shloks.practicalExplanation: All beings — mobile or immobile — arise from the union of matter (field) and spirit (knower). Life emerges where consciousness meets matter. This union creates all manifest existence.
shloks.strengthReflection: All life arises from the union of matter and consciousness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, in the union of field and knower, Your creative power manifests.

shloks.sanskrit: समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम्। विनश्यत्स्वविनश्यन्तं यः पश्यति स पश्यति॥
shloks.transliteration: samaṁ sarveṣhu bhūteṣhu tiṣhṭhantaṁ parameśhvaram vinaśhyatsv avinaśhyantaṁ yaḥ paśhyati sa paśhyati
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who sees the Supreme Lord dwelling equally in all beings, imperishable within the perishable — that one truly sees.
shloks.practicalExplanation: True vision is seeing the same Supreme Lord in all beings — the imperishable soul within perishable bodies. One who sees this unity amidst diversity truly sees. This is the vision that liberates.
shloks.strengthReflection: I strive to see the imperishable Lord equally present in all beings.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me the vision to see You equally in all beings.

shloks.sanskrit: समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम्। न हिनस्त्यात्मनात्मानं ततो याति परां गतिम्॥
shloks.transliteration: samaṁ paśhyan hi sarvatra samavasthitam īśhvaram na hinasty ātmanātmānaṁ tato yāti parāṁ gatim
shloks.simpleMeaning: Seeing the Lord equally present everywhere, one does not harm the Self by the self, and thus attains the supreme goal.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When you see God equally everywhere, you cannot harm others because you see yourself in them. By not hurting the Self (in others), you don't degrade yourself. This vision of unity leads to the highest goal.
shloks.strengthReflection: Seeing God everywhere, I harm no one, protect my soul, and attain the highest.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me see You everywhere and harm none, attaining the supreme goal.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः। यः पश्यति तथात्मानमकर्तारं स पश्यति॥
shloks.transliteration: prakṛityaiva cha karmāṇi kriyamāṇāni sarvaśhaḥ yaḥ paśhyati tathātmānam akartāraṁ sa paśhyati
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who sees that all actions are performed by Prakriti alone and that the Self is not the doer — that one truly sees.
shloks.practicalExplanation: True vision includes seeing that all actions are done by nature (Prakriti) through the body-mind, while the soul is the non-acting witness. The Self is akarta — non-doer. This understanding frees from ego and its karmic bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see that nature performs all actions while my true Self is the non-acting witness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me realize that all actions are Yours through nature; I am the witness.

shloks.sanskrit: यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति। तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म संपद्यते तदा॥
shloks.transliteration: yadā bhūta-pṛithag-bhāvam eka-stham anupaśhyati tata eva cha vistāraṁ brahma sampadyate tadā
shloks.simpleMeaning: When one perceives the diversity of beings as rooted in the One and their expansion as from That alone — then one attains Brahman.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Liberation comes when you see all diverse beings rooted in one Source and their expansion emanating from That One. Unity in diversity, diversity from unity — this vision of the One in the many is the gateway to Brahman.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see all diverse beings rooted in One and expanding from that One.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, reveal to me the One Source from which all diversity emerges.

shloks.sanskrit: अनादित्वान्निर्गुणत्वात्परमात्मायमव्ययः। शरीरस्थोऽपि कौन्तेय न करोति न लिप्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: anāditvān nirguṇatvāt paramātmāyam avyayaḥ śharīra-stho 'pi kaunteya na karoti na lipyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Being beginningless and without qualities, this imperishable Supreme Self, though dwelling in the body, O Kaunteya, neither acts nor is tainted.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The Supreme Self, being eternal and without material qualities, though residing in the body, neither performs actions nor is stained by them. Like space in a pot isn't affected by the pot's condition, the soul is untouched by bodily activities.
shloks.strengthReflection: My true Self is eternal, quality-less, non-acting, and unstained by bodily activities.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me realize my unchanging, untainted nature beyond all bodily actions.

shloks.sanskrit: यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते। सर्वत्रावस्थितो देहे तथात्मा नोपलिप्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: yathā sarva-gataṁ saukṣhmyād ākāśhaṁ nopalipyate sarvatrāvasthito dehe tathātmā nopalipyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: As the all-pervading space is not tainted due to its subtlety, so the Self, though present everywhere in the body, is not tainted.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Space pervades everything yet nothing sticks to it — because it is subtle. Similarly, the soul pervades the body without being tainted by its activities, emotions, or conditions. The soul's subtlety keeps it ever pure.
shloks.strengthReflection: Like space, my soul pervades but is never tainted by what it pervades.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me realize my soul's purity like space — present everywhere, touching nothing.

shloks.sanskrit: यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः। क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत॥
shloks.transliteration: yathā prakāśhayaty ekaḥ kṛitsnaṁ lokam imaṁ raviḥ kṣhetraṁ kṣhetrī tathā kṛitsnaṁ prakāśhayati bhārata
shloks.simpleMeaning: As the one sun illumines this whole world, so the Lord of the field illumines the entire field, O Bharata.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Just as one sun illuminates the whole world without being divided, one soul illuminates the entire body. The knower of the field (soul/God) gives consciousness to the whole body-mind field. Consciousness is one; its reflections are many.
shloks.strengthReflection: My one consciousness illuminates my entire body-mind, like the sun illuminates the world.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the one light illuminating all fields of experience.

shloks.sanskrit: क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवमन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा। भूतप्रकृतिमोक्षं च ये विदुर्यान्ति ते परम्॥
shloks.transliteration: kṣhetra-kṣhetrajñayor evam antaraṁ jñāna-chakṣhuṣhā bhūta-prakṛiti-mokṣhaṁ cha ye vidur yānti te param
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those who, with the eye of knowledge, perceive the difference between the field and the knower of the field, and the liberation from the nature of beings — they attain the Supreme.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those who discriminate between field (body-mind) and knower (soul), and understand how beings are liberated from material nature — they attain the Supreme. The 'eye of knowledge' is discriminative wisdom that sees what is real and unreal.
shloks.strengthReflection: With the eye of knowledge, I discern field from knower and attain liberation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me the eye of knowledge to see the difference and attain the Supreme.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम्। यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣhyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: I shall again declare that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, knowing which all the sages have attained the highest perfection.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna introduces the teaching on the three gunas as the highest knowledge. All sages who understood this attained supreme perfection. This knowledge is the key to understanding material nature and transcending it.
shloks.strengthReflection: I receive this supreme knowledge that leads to the highest perfection.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, share with me the highest knowledge that liberates all sages.

shloks.sanskrit: इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः। सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च॥
shloks.transliteration: idaṁ jñānam upāśhritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ sarge 'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: By resorting to this knowledge, having attained identity with Me, they are not born at creation nor disturbed at dissolution.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those who grasp this knowledge attain God's own nature — same qualities, same freedom. They are beyond the cosmic cycles of creation and dissolution, unaffected by universal beginnings and endings.
shloks.strengthReflection: This knowledge leads me to God's nature, beyond all cosmic cycles.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, through this knowledge, let me attain Your eternal nature beyond all changes.

shloks.sanskrit: मम योनिर्महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम्। संभवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत॥
shloks.transliteration: mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbhaṁ dadhāmy aham sambhavaḥ sarva-bhūtānāṁ tato bhavati bhārata
shloks.simpleMeaning: The great Brahman (Prakriti) is My womb. In that I place the seed. From that arises the birth of all beings, O Bharata.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Prakriti (material nature) is the womb, the mother. God places the seed of consciousness. From their union, all beings are born. Matter provides the body; God provides the life-force. Both are needed for creation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am born from the union of matter and divine consciousness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the Father placing consciousness in the womb of nature.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः संभवन्ति याः। तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता॥
shloks.transliteration: sarva-yoniṣhu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ tāsāṁ brahma mahad yonir ahaṁ bīja-pradaḥ pitā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Whatever forms are produced in all wombs, O son of Kunti, the great Brahman (Prakriti) is their womb, and I am the seed-giving Father.
shloks.practicalExplanation: All life-forms, in all species, arise from the same process: matter as mother, God as father. From amoeba to human, the pattern is identical. This unifies all creation under one parentage — one Divine Father.
shloks.strengthReflection: God is the Father of all beings; material nature is the universal mother.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the Father of all beings. I am Your child.

shloks.sanskrit: सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसंभवाः। निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्॥
shloks.transliteration: sattvaṁ rajas tama iti guṇāḥ prakṛiti-sambhavāḥ nibadhnanti mahā-bāho dehe dehinam avyayam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas — these qualities born of Prakriti bind the imperishable soul in the body, O mighty-armed one.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The three gunas — sattva (goodness/purity), rajas (passion/activity), and tamas (ignorance/inertia) — are nature's fundamental qualities. Though the soul is imperishable, these gunas bind it to the body through identification.
shloks.strengthReflection: The three gunas — sattva, rajas, tamas — bind me to the body until I transcend them.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me understand these gunas so I may transcend their bondage.

shloks.sanskrit: तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्। सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ॥
shloks.transliteration: tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt prakāśhakam anāmayam sukha-saṅgena badhnāti jñāna-saṅgena chānagha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Of these, sattva, being pure, is illuminating and free from disease. It binds through attachment to happiness and attachment to knowledge, O sinless one.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattva is the purest guna — luminous, healthy, clear. But even it binds! Through attachment to happiness and knowledge. The spiritual seeker can get attached to blissful states and intellectual understanding, creating subtle bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: Even attachment to happiness and knowledge can bind me. I seek freedom beyond sattva.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me enjoy purity without attachment to its happiness or knowledge.

shloks.sanskrit: रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम्। तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम्॥
shloks.transliteration: rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛiṣhṇā-saṅga-samudbhavam tan nibadhnāti kaunteya karma-saṅgena dehinam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Know rajas to be of the nature of passion, arising from craving and attachment. It binds the embodied soul through attachment to action, O son of Kunti.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajas is passion, desire, craving. It creates restlessness and constant activity. It binds through attachment to work and its fruits. The rajasic person is never satisfied, always wanting more, doing more.
shloks.strengthReflection: Rajas binds me through restless craving and attachment to action's fruits.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, calm my rajas. Let me act without craving or attachment.

shloks.sanskrit: तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्। प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत॥
shloks.transliteration: tamas tv ajñāna-jaṁ viddhi mohanaṁ sarva-dehinām pramādālasya-nidrābhis tan nibadhnāti bhārata
shloks.simpleMeaning: Know tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings. It binds through negligence, laziness, and sleep, O Bharata.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamas is ignorance, darkness, inertia. It deludes all beings into confusion and apathy. It binds through carelessness, laziness, and excessive sleep. The tamasic person avoids action, remains confused, sleeps too much.
shloks.strengthReflection: Tamas binds me through ignorance, laziness, and excessive sleep.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, dispel my tamas. Awaken me from ignorance and inertia.

shloks.sanskrit: सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत। ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत॥
shloks.transliteration: sattvaṁ sukhe sañjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata jñānam āvṛitya tu tamaḥ pramāde sañjayaty uta
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sattva attaches one to happiness, rajas to action, O Bharata, while tamas, veiling knowledge, attaches to negligence.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Each guna creates its characteristic attachment: sattva to happiness and peace, rajas to activity and achievement, tamas to carelessness and avoidance. Recognizing which guna dominates helps us work toward balance and transcendence.
shloks.strengthReflection: I observe which guna dominates my current state and work toward transcendence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me recognize and transcend all three types of attachment.

shloks.sanskrit: रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत। रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा॥
shloks.transliteration: rajas tamaśh chābhibhūya sattvaṁ bhavati bhārata rajaḥ sattvaṁ tamaśh chaiva tamaḥ sattvaṁ rajas tathā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sattva prevails by overcoming rajas and tamas, O Bharata. Rajas prevails by overcoming sattva and tamas. Similarly, tamas prevails by overcoming sattva and rajas.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The gunas constantly compete for dominance. When sattva prevails, we feel peaceful and clear. When rajas dominates, we are restless and driven. When tamas takes over, we are dull and confused. This is the constant inner battle.
shloks.strengthReflection: I observe the interplay of gunas within me, watching which one dominates.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, strengthen sattva within me and help me transcend all three gunas.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते। ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत॥
shloks.transliteration: sarva-dvāreṣhu dehe 'smin prakāśha upajāyate jñānaṁ yadā tadā vidyād vivṛiddhaṁ sattvam ity uta
shloks.simpleMeaning: When the light of knowledge shines through all the gates of the body, then know that sattva is predominant.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Signs of sattva dominance: clarity shines through all senses, understanding is present, inner illumination is felt. The 'gates' are the senses — when perception is clear and knowledge arises naturally, sattva is strong.
shloks.strengthReflection: When clarity and knowledge shine, I recognize sattva's positive influence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let sattva's light shine through all my senses and faculties.

shloks.sanskrit: लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा। रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ॥
shloks.transliteration: lobhaḥ pravṛittir ārambhaḥ karmaṇām aśhamaḥ spṛihā rajasy etāni jāyante vivṛiddhe bharatarṣhabha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Greed, activity, undertaking of actions, restlessness, and craving — these arise when rajas predominates, O best of the Bharatas.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Signs of rajas dominance: greed arises, constant activity drives you, you start new projects compulsively, inner restlessness disturbs peace, desires multiply. Recognizing these symptoms helps you see rajas at work.
shloks.strengthReflection: When greed, restlessness, and constant craving arise, I recognize rajas' influence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, calm my rajas when its restlessness disturbs my peace.

shloks.sanskrit: अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च। तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन॥
shloks.transliteration: aprakāśho 'pravṛittiśh cha pramādo moha eva cha tamasy etāni jāyante vivṛiddhe kuru-nandana
shloks.simpleMeaning: Darkness, inactivity, negligence, and delusion — these arise when tamas predominates, O descendant of Kuru.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Signs of tamas dominance: mental darkness and dullness, inability to act, carelessness about important matters, confusion and delusion. When you feel fog in mind and body, tamas is strong.
shloks.strengthReflection: When darkness, inaction, and confusion arise, I recognize tamas' influence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, dispel tamas' darkness with Your light of knowledge.

shloks.sanskrit: यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत्। तदोत्तमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: yadā sattve pravṛiddhe tu pralayaṁ yāti deha-bhṛit tadottama-vidāṁ lokān amalān pratipadyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: When the embodied one dies while sattva prevails, then one attains the pure worlds of those who know the highest.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Death during sattvic dominance leads to pure, luminous realms — worlds of the wise and pure. The state at death influences the next destination. Cultivating sattva ensures a better rebirth or liberation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate sattva so that my transition leads to higher realms.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let sattva prevail in me, especially at life's transition.

shloks.sanskrit: रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते। तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते॥
shloks.transliteration: rajasi pralayaṁ gatvā karma-saṅgiṣhu jāyate tathā pralīnas tamasi mūḍha-yoniṣhu jāyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Dying in rajas, one is born among those attached to action. Dying in tamas, one is born in the wombs of the deluded.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Death in rajas leads to rebirth among active, ambitious beings — driven but not liberated. Death in tamas leads to birth in confused, dull conditions — animal or degraded human states. Our dominant quality shapes our destiny.
shloks.strengthReflection: I understand that my dominant quality at death shapes my next birth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify me so that neither rajas nor tamas dominate at my end.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम्। रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम्॥
shloks.transliteration: karmaṇaḥ sukṛitasyāhuḥ sāttvikaṁ nirmalaṁ phalam rajasas tu phalaṁ duḥkham ajñānaṁ tamasaḥ phalam
shloks.simpleMeaning: The fruit of sattvic action is said to be pure; the fruit of rajas is pain; the fruit of tamas is ignorance.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Actions done in sattva yield pure, lasting results. Rajasic actions produce pain despite apparent success. Tamasic actions produce ignorance and confusion. The quality of the action determines the quality of the fruit.
shloks.strengthReflection: I perform sattvic actions for pure results, avoiding rajasic pain and tamasic ignorance.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let all my actions be sattvic, yielding pure and liberating fruits.

shloks.sanskrit: सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च। प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च॥
shloks.transliteration: sattvāt sañjāyate jñānaṁ rajaso lobha eva cha pramāda-mohau tamaso bhavato 'jñānam eva cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: From sattva arises knowledge; from rajas, greed; and from tamas arise negligence, delusion, and ignorance.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Each guna produces its natural fruit: sattva gives knowledge and wisdom, rajas produces greed and craving, tamas generates carelessness, confusion, and ignorance. We can trace our mental states to their guna-sources.
shloks.strengthReflection: I trace my knowledge to sattva, my cravings to rajas, my confusion to tamas.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, increase my sattva so that knowledge may grow within me.

shloks.sanskrit: ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः। जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः॥
shloks.transliteration: ūrdhvaṁ gachchhanti sattva-sthā madhye tiṣhṭhanti rājasāḥ jaghanya-guṇa-vṛitti-sthā adho gachchhanti tāmasāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those established in sattva rise upward; the rajasic dwell in the middle; the tamasic, abiding in the function of the lowest guna, go downward.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The gunas determine direction: sattvic beings evolve upward toward higher states, rajasic beings remain in the middle — worldly existence, tamasic beings descend to lower births. We choose our direction by our guna-cultivation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate sattva to rise upward in consciousness and evolution.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, lift me upward through sattva to higher states of being.

shloks.sanskrit: नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति। गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति॥
shloks.transliteration: nānyaṁ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṁ yadā draṣhṭānupaśhyati guṇebhyaśh cha paraṁ vetti mad-bhāvaṁ so 'dhigachchhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: When the seer perceives no doer other than the gunas and knows what is beyond the gunas — he attains My nature.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Liberation comes when you see that only the gunas act — there is no separate doer. And you know yourself as beyond all gunas — the witnessing consciousness. This insight leads to Krishna's own nature, divine freedom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see the gunas as the only doer and know myself as the witness beyond them.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me see that gunas alone act while I am the witness attaining Your nature.

shloks.sanskrit: गुणानेतानतीत्य त्रीन्देही देहसमुद्भवान्। जन्ममृत्युजरादुःखैर्विमुक्तोऽमृतमश्नुते॥
shloks.transliteration: guṇān etān atītya trīn dehī deha-samudbhavān janma-mṛityu-jarā-duḥkhair vimukto 'mṛitam aśhnute
shloks.simpleMeaning: The embodied one, transcending these three gunas from which the body arises, is freed from birth, death, old age, and sorrow, and attains immortality.
shloks.practicalExplanation: By transcending all three gunas — even sattva — the soul is freed from rebirth, aging, death, and suffering. Immortality is attained. The goal is not to perfect one guna but to transcend all material qualities.
shloks.strengthReflection: By transcending all gunas, I attain freedom from birth, death, and suffering.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me transcend all three gunas and attain immortality.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। कैर्लिङ्गैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतानतीतो भवति प्रभो। किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तते॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha kair liṅgais trīn guṇān etān atīto bhavati prabho kim āchāraḥ kathaṁ chaitāṁs trīn guṇān ativartate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: By what signs is one who has transcended these three gunas known, O Lord? What is his conduct, and how does he transcend the three gunas?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna asks the practical questions: How do we recognize someone who has transcended the gunas? What is their behavior? How did they achieve this transcendence? These questions bring the teaching into actionable understanding.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek to understand the signs, conduct, and method of one who transcends the gunas.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, show me the signs of transcendence and how to achieve it.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव। न द्वेष्टि संप्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha prakāśhaṁ cha pravṛittiṁ cha moham eva cha pāṇḍava na dveṣhṭi sampravṛittāni na nivṛittāni kāṅkṣhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: He who does not hate illumination, activity, or delusion when present, nor longs for them when absent, O Pandava...
shloks.practicalExplanation: The transcended one doesn't hate any guna's manifestation (sattva's light, rajas' activity, tamas' delusion) nor craves them when absent. This equanimity toward all guna-states indicates freedom from their grip.
shloks.strengthReflection: I neither hate nor crave the manifestations of any guna.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me equanimity toward all states — neither hating nor craving.

shloks.sanskrit: उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते। गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येवं योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गते॥
shloks.transliteration: udāsīna-vad āsīno guṇair yo na vichālyate guṇā vartanta ity evaṁ yo 'vatiṣhṭhati neṅgate
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...seated as if unconcerned, undisturbed by the gunas, knowing that the gunas alone are acting — he remains steady and does not waver.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The transcended one sits like an unconcerned witness — not cold or uncaring, but unmoved by internal guna-fluctuations. Knowing that only the gunas act (not the self), they remain steady, unwavering, established in being.
shloks.strengthReflection: I remain steady as the witness, knowing the gunas alone act through my body-mind.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, establish me as the unmoved witness, steady amid all guna-fluctuations.

shloks.sanskrit: समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः। तुल्यप्रियाप्रियो धीरस्तुल्यनिन्दात्मसंस्तुतिः॥
shloks.transliteration: sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ sva-sthaḥ sama-loṣhṭāśhma-kāñchanaḥ tulya-priyāpriyo dhīras tulya-nindātma-saṁstutiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Alike in pleasure and pain, self-reliant, regarding clod, stone, and gold equally, equal toward pleasant and unpleasant, firm, the same in blame and praise...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Characteristics continue: equal in pleasure and pain (inner balance), self-reliant (centered in self), seeing material things equally (a clod = stone = gold), unaffected by pleasant or unpleasant, firm, unmoved by criticism or praise.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am equally balanced in pleasure-pain, praise-blame, seeing all things equally.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, establish me in this equanimity that sees all equally.

shloks.sanskrit: मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः। सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: mānāpamānayos tulyas tulyo mitrāri-pakṣhayoḥ sarvārambha-parityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...the same in honor and dishonor, equal toward friend and foe, renouncing all undertakings — he is said to have transcended the gunas.
shloks.practicalExplanation: More signs: equal in honor and dishonor (ego unmoved), same toward friends and enemies (universal love), renouncing all ego-driven undertakings (not initiating actions for personal gain). This describes one who has transcended all three gunas.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am the same in honor-dishonor, with friend-enemy, renouncing ego-driven actions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me transcend the gunas by renouncing ego-driven undertakings.

shloks.sanskrit: मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते। स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान्ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते॥
shloks.transliteration: māṁ cha yo 'vyabhichāreṇa bhakti-yogena sevate sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahma-bhūyāya kalpate
shloks.simpleMeaning: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotion, transcending these gunas, is fit to become Brahman.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Here's the method: unwavering devotion to Krishna! Bhakti yoga transcends all gunas. Not by effort of will but by love of God, one rises beyond material nature. Devotion makes one fit for Brahman-realization.
shloks.strengthReflection: Through unwavering devotion, I transcend the gunas and become fit for Brahman.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, through my devoted service to You, let me transcend all gunas.

shloks.sanskrit: ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च। शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च॥
shloks.transliteration: brahmaṇo hi pratiṣhṭhāham amṛitasyāvyayasya cha śhāśhvatasya cha dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya cha
shloks.simpleMeaning: For I am the foundation of Brahman, of the immortal and imperishable, of the eternal dharma, and of absolute bliss.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna reveals His supreme position: He is the foundation of Brahman itself, of immortality, of eternal righteousness, and of absolute bliss. The impersonal Brahman rests on the personal God. Krishna is the support of everything.
shloks.strengthReflection: Krishna is the foundation of Brahman, immortality, dharma, and ultimate bliss.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the foundation of all. In You, I find immortality and bliss.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम्। छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित्॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha ūrdhva-mūlam adhaḥ-śhākham aśhvatthaṁ prāhur avyayam chhandānsi yasya parṇāni yas taṁ veda sa veda-vit
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: They speak of an imperishable Ashvattha tree with roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the Vedas. One who knows this tree knows the Vedas.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The world is compared to an eternal fig tree (Ashvattha) with roots in the Supreme (above) and branches spreading below. The Vedic hymns are its leaves. Understanding this metaphor of creation is knowing the essence of all scriptures.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see the world as a cosmic tree rooted in the Divine, sustained by sacred knowledge.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me understand this cosmic tree rooted in You.

shloks.sanskrit: अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवालाः। अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके॥
shloks.transliteration: adhaśh chordhvaṁ prasṛitās tasya śhākhā guṇa-pravṛiddhā viṣhaya-pravālāḥ adhaśh cha mūlāny anusantatāni karmānubandhīni manuṣhya-loke
shloks.simpleMeaning: Its branches extend below and above, nourished by the gunas, with sense objects as buds. Its roots stretch below, bound to actions in the human world.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The tree's branches (life-forms) spread through all worlds, nourished by the three gunas. Sense objects are its tender shoots that attract us. Secondary roots (desires based on past karma) bind beings in the human world.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see how desires and past actions bind me to this tree of worldly existence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me understand the roots that bind me to worldly existence.

shloks.sanskrit: न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते नान्तो न चादिर्न च संप्रतिष्ठा। अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूलमसङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा॥
shloks.transliteration: na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na chādir na cha sampratiṣhṭhā aśhvattham enaṁ su-virūḍha-mūlam asaṅga-śhastreṇa dṛiḍhena chhittvā
shloks.simpleMeaning: Its form is not perceived here as such, nor its end, beginning, or foundation. Cutting this firmly-rooted Ashvattha tree with the strong axe of non-attachment...
shloks.practicalExplanation: This tree cannot be seen clearly from within — we cannot perceive its full extent, origin, or foundation while entangled in it. The only way to be free is to cut it with the sharp axe of non-attachment (asanga).
shloks.strengthReflection: I use the axe of non-attachment to cut the roots binding me to worldly existence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, sharpen my axe of non-attachment to cut through worldly bondage.

shloks.sanskrit: ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः। तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी॥
shloks.transliteration: tataḥ padaṁ tat parimārgitavyaṁ yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ tam eva chādyaṁ puruṣhaṁ prapadye yataḥ pravṛittiḥ prasṛitā purāṇī
shloks.simpleMeaning: Then that goal should be sought, reaching which one does not return again. 'I take refuge in that Primeval Person from whom the ancient activity has flowed.'
shloks.practicalExplanation: After cutting attachments, seek the goal from which there is no return — liberation. Take refuge in the Primeval Person (God) from whom all creation originally flowed. This surrender is the way to eternal freedom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek the supreme goal and take refuge in the Primeval Person.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I take refuge in You, the Primeval Person from whom all flows.

shloks.sanskrit: निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः। द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञैर्गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत्॥
shloks.transliteration: nirmāna-mohā jita-saṅga-doṣhā adhyātma-nityā vinivṛitta-kāmāḥ dvandvair vimuktāḥ sukha-duḥkha-saṁjñair gachchhanty amūḍhāḥ padam avyayaṁ tat
shloks.simpleMeaning: Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, ever dwelling in the Self, desires completely stilled, liberated from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain — the undeluded reach that imperishable goal.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Who reaches the eternal goal? Those free from ego and delusion, who conquered attachment, absorbed in the Self, free from desires, liberated from pleasure-pain dualities. These clear-minded ones attain the imperishable state.
shloks.strengthReflection: I free myself from ego, attachment, and dualities to reach the eternal goal.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from pride, delusion, and attachment so I may reach Your eternal abode.

shloks.sanskrit: न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः। यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम॥
