shloks.transliteration: na tad bhāsayate sūryo na śhaśhāṅko na pāvakaḥ yad gatvā na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama
shloks.simpleMeaning: Neither sun, nor moon, nor fire illumines that place — reaching it, none return. That is My supreme abode.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna's supreme abode is self-luminous — it doesn't need sun, moon, or fire for light. It is beyond material energy, eternal, and those who reach it never return to material existence. This is the ultimate destination.
shloks.strengthReflection: The supreme abode is self-luminous, eternal, and beyond all return.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me reach Your supreme abode from which no one returns.

shloks.sanskrit: ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः। मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति॥
shloks.transliteration: mamaivānśho jīva-loke jīva-bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ manaḥ-ṣhaṣhṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛiti-sthāni karṣhati
shloks.simpleMeaning: An eternal fragment of Myself, having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the mind and the five senses which rest in Prakriti.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Every soul is an eternal fragment of God. When the soul enters material existence, it attracts a mind and five senses. This creates the body-mind complex. We are divine sparks temporarily clothed in matter.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am an eternal fragment of God, temporarily associated with mind and senses.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I am Your eternal part. Help me remember my divine origin.

shloks.sanskrit: शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः। गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात्॥
shloks.transliteration: śharīraṁ yad avāpnoti yach chāpy utkrāmatīśhvaraḥ gṛihītvaitāni saṁyāti vāyur gandhān ivāśhayāt
shloks.simpleMeaning: When the Lord (soul) acquires a body and when He leaves it, He takes these (mind and senses) and goes, as the wind carries scents from their source.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When the soul enters a new body or leaves an old one, it carries the mind and sense impressions with it — like wind carrying fragrance from flowers. Death is just the soul moving with its subtle body to another form.
shloks.strengthReflection: At death, I carry my mental impressions to the next body, like wind carries scent.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my subtle body so I carry only Your fragrance into my next life.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च। अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrotraṁ chakṣhuḥ sparśhanaṁ cha rasanaṁ ghrāṇam eva cha adhiṣhṭhāya manaśh chāyaṁ viṣhayān upasevate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Presiding over the ear, eye, touch, taste, and smell, as well as the mind, he enjoys the objects of the senses.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Once embodied, the soul presides over hearing, sight, touch, taste, smell, and mind — and through these enjoys sense objects. The soul is the enjoyer, the senses are instruments. Without the soul, senses cannot experience.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am the conscious enjoyer presiding over my senses and mind.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me use my senses in Your service, not for mere sense enjoyment.

shloks.sanskrit: उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम्। विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः॥
shloks.transliteration: utkrāmantaṁ sthitaṁ vāpi bhuñjānaṁ vā guṇānvitam vimūḍhā nānupaśhyanti paśhyanti jñāna-chakṣhuṣhaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The deluded do not perceive the soul departing, staying, or enjoying, associated with the gunas. But those with the eye of knowledge see.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The ignorant cannot perceive the soul — whether it leaves the body, stays, or experiences the gunas. But those with wisdom-vision can see the soul's journey through bodies. Spiritual vision sees what physical eyes miss.
shloks.strengthReflection: With the eye of wisdom, I perceive the soul's journey that the deluded miss.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me the eye of knowledge to see the soul beyond the body.

shloks.sanskrit: यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम्। यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः॥
shloks.transliteration: yatanto yoginaśh chainaṁ paśhyanty ātmany avasthitam yatanto 'py akṛitātmāno nainaṁ paśhyanty achetasaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Striving yogis perceive this Self established in themselves. But the unrefined, though striving, do not perceive this Self, lacking in understanding.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sincere yogis, through effort and practice, perceive the Self within. But those with impure minds, even if they try, cannot see it — their hearts are not prepared. Inner purification is essential for self-realization.
shloks.strengthReflection: Through sincere practice and purification, I strive to perceive the Self within.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my heart so I may perceive the Self through devoted practice.

shloks.sanskrit: यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम्। यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yad āditya-gataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate 'khilam yach chandramasi yach chāgnau tat tejo viddhi māmakam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Know that the splendor in the sun that illumines the whole world, and that which is in the moon and in fire — that splendor is Mine.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The light of the sun illuminating the world, the glow of the moon, the brilliance of fire — all this radiance is Krishna's. The universe's luminosity is God's splendor manifested. Every light reflects Divine light.
shloks.strengthReflection: Every light I see — sun, moon, fire — is a reflection of God's splendor.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me see Your splendor in all sources of light.

shloks.sanskrit: गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा। पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः॥
shloks.transliteration: gām āviśhya cha bhūtāni dhārayāmy aham ojasā puṣhṇāmi chauṣhadhīḥ sarvāḥ somo bhūtvā rasātmakaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Entering the earth, I sustain all beings by My power. Becoming the watery moon (Soma), I nourish all plants.
shloks.practicalExplanation: God enters the earth and sustains all creatures through its nourishing power. As the moon's nectar (soma), He nourishes all plants with vital essence. Agriculture and nourishment depend on divine energy permeating nature.
shloks.strengthReflection: God sustains all beings through the earth and nourishes all plants through the moon.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I see Your sustaining presence in the earth and nourishing plants.

shloks.sanskrit: अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः। प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम्॥
shloks.transliteration: ahaṁ vaiśhvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṁ deham āśhritaḥ prāṇāpāna-samāyuktaḥ pachāmy annaṁ chatur-vidham
shloks.simpleMeaning: Becoming the digestive fire (Vaishvanara) in the bodies of living beings, joined with Prana and Apana, I digest the four kinds of food.
shloks.practicalExplanation: God becomes the digestive fire in every body. Working with incoming and outgoing breath (prana and apana), He digests all four types of food (chewed, sucked, licked, and drunk). Digestion is a divine process.
shloks.strengthReflection: The fire that digests my food is divine presence working within me.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I see You as the digestive fire nourishing my body from within.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च। वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम्॥
shloks.transliteration: sarvasya chāhaṁ hṛidi sanniviṣhṭo mattaḥ smṛitir jñānam apohanaṁ cha vedaiśh cha sarvair aham eva vedyo vedānta-kṛid veda-vid eva chāham
shloks.simpleMeaning: I am seated in the hearts of all. From Me come memory, knowledge, and their removal. I alone am to be known through all the Vedas. I am the author of Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas.
shloks.practicalExplanation: God dwells in every heart. Memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness all come from Him. All Vedas aim to reveal Him. He is Vedanta's author and the Vedas' true knower. The innermost Self is God.
shloks.strengthReflection: God is in my heart, the source of my memory, knowledge, and all understanding.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You dwell in my heart. All my knowing and forgetting come from You.

shloks.sanskrit: द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च। क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: dvāv imau puruṣhau loke kṣharaśh chākṣhara eva cha kṣharaḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni kūṭa-stho 'kṣhara uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: There are two types of beings in the world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable; the unchanging is called imperishable.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Two types of Purusha (beings) exist: the perishable (all creatures — bodies that decay) and the imperishable (the eternal soul that doesn't change). Distinguishing between body and soul is fundamental wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: My body is perishable; my soul is imperishable and unchanging.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me identify with the imperishable soul, not the perishable body.

shloks.sanskrit: उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युदाहृतः। यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः॥
shloks.transliteration: uttamaḥ puruṣhas tv anyaḥ paramātmety udāhṛitaḥ yo loka-trayam āviśhya bibharty avyaya īśhvaraḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: But there is another, the Supreme Person, called the Supreme Self, the imperishable Lord who, pervading the three worlds, sustains them.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Beyond perishable bodies and imperishable souls is a third: the Supreme Person (Purushottama). This is God — who pervades all three worlds (heaven, earth, underworld) and sustains everything. He is above both matter and individual souls.
shloks.strengthReflection: Beyond perishable and imperishable is the Supreme Person who sustains all worlds.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the Supreme Person, beyond all, sustaining all three worlds.

shloks.sanskrit: यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः। अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः॥
shloks.transliteration: yasmāt kṣharam atīto 'ham akṣharād api chottamaḥ ato 'smi loke vede cha prathitaḥ puruṣhottamaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Because I transcend the perishable and am even above the imperishable, I am known in the world and in the Vedas as the Supreme Person (Purushottama).
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna declares His supreme position: He transcends perishable matter and is even above imperishable souls. Therefore scriptures and the world know Him as Purushottama — the Supreme Person, highest of all beings.
shloks.strengthReflection: Krishna is Purushottama — above both the perishable and the imperishable.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are Purushottama, supreme above all. I worship You as the highest.

shloks.sanskrit: यो मामेवमसंमूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम्। स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत॥
shloks.transliteration: yo mām evam asaṁmūḍho jānāti puruṣhottamam sa sarva-vid bhajati māṁ sarva-bhāvena bhārata
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who, undeluded, knows Me thus as the Supreme Person — that all-knowing one worships Me with all his being, O Bharata.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Whoever knows Krishna as the Supreme Person without delusion — that person is all-knowing and worships Krishna with their entire being. Full understanding of Krishna's supremacy leads to complete devotion.
shloks.strengthReflection: Knowing Krishna as the Supreme Person, I worship Him with my whole being.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, knowing You as Purushottama, I devote myself to You completely.

shloks.sanskrit: इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ। एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत॥
shloks.transliteration: iti guhyatamaṁ śhāstram idam uktaṁ mayānagha etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛita-kṛityaśh cha bhārata
shloks.simpleMeaning: Thus this most secret teaching has been imparted by Me, O sinless one. Understanding this, one becomes wise and has fulfilled all duties, O Bharata.
shloks.practicalExplanation: This is the most secret teaching — understanding the Supreme Person. Grasping this knowledge makes one truly wise and accomplishes life's purpose. Nothing more needs to be done. This is the culmination of wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: Understanding this supreme teaching, I become wise and fulfill my life's purpose.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, having heard this secret teaching, let me be wise and complete.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः। दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम्॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha abhayaṁ sattva-sanśhuddhir jñāna-yoga-vyavasthitiḥ dānaṁ damaśh cha yajñaśh cha svādhyāyas tapa ārjavam
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and yoga, charity, self-control, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity, straightforwardness...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna begins listing divine qualities: fearlessness (especially of death), inner purity, dedication to knowledge and yoga, generosity, sense control, performing sacred observances, self-study of scriptures, discipline, and honesty.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate fearlessness, purity, charity, control, study, austerity, and honesty.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, develop these divine qualities within me.

shloks.sanskrit: अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम्। दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम्॥
shloks.transliteration: ahiṁsā satyam akrodhas tyāgaḥ śhāntir apaiśhunam dayā bhūteṣhv aloluptvaṁ mārdavaṁ hrīr achāpalam
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...non-violence, truthfulness, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of slander, compassion to all beings, freedom from greed, gentleness, modesty, absence of fickleness...
shloks.practicalExplanation: More divine qualities: non-violence, truthfulness, freedom from anger, letting go, inner peace, not speaking ill of others, compassion for all creatures, non-covetousness, gentleness, sense of modesty, steadiness.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice non-violence, truth, peace, compassion, gentleness, and steadiness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, fill me with compassion, peace, and freedom from anger.

shloks.sanskrit: तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता। भवन्ति संपदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत॥
shloks.transliteration: tejaḥ kṣhamā dhṛitiḥ śhaucham adroho nātimānitā bhavanti sampadaṁ daivīm abhijātasya bhārata
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, cleanliness, freedom from malice, absence of excessive pride — these belong to one born with divine qualities, O Bharata.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The list concludes: energy, patience, determination, purity, non-hatred, humility. These 26 qualities constitute divine nature (daivi sampat). One born with these qualities is destined for liberation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I develop vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, cleanliness, and humility.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me be born with divine qualities leading to liberation.

shloks.sanskrit: दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च। अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ संपदमासुरीम्॥
shloks.transliteration: dambho darpo 'bhimānaśh cha krodhaḥ pāruṣhyam eva cha ajñānaṁ chābhijātasya pārtha sampadam āsurīm
shloks.simpleMeaning: Hypocrisy, arrogance, self-conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance — these belong to one born with demoniac qualities, O Partha.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Now the demoniac qualities: pretense, pride, vanity, anger, cruelty, and ignorance. These six constitute the demoniac nature (asuri sampat). One born with these qualities is heading toward bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize and remove hypocrisy, pride, anger, cruelty, and ignorance from myself.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, remove from me all traces of demoniac nature.

shloks.sanskrit: दैवी संपद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता। मा शुचः संपदं दैवीमभिजातोऽसि पाण्डव॥
shloks.transliteration: daivī sampad vimokṣhāya nibandhāyāsurī matā mā śhuchaḥ sampadaṁ daivīm abhijāto 'si pāṇḍava
shloks.simpleMeaning: Divine nature leads to liberation; demoniac nature leads to bondage. Do not grieve, O Pandava — you are born with divine qualities.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The results are clear: divine qualities lead to liberation, demoniac qualities to bondage. Krishna reassures Arjuna that he has divine nature — no need to worry. We can examine ourselves and cultivate divine qualities.
shloks.strengthReflection: I choose divine qualities that lead to liberation, not demoniac ones that bind.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I trust Your assurance. Help me strengthen my divine nature.

shloks.sanskrit: द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन्दैव आसुर एव च। दैवो विस्तरशः प्रोक्त आसुरं पार्थ मे शृणु॥
shloks.transliteration: dvau bhūta-sargau loke 'smin daiva āsura eva cha daivo vistaraśhaḥ prokta āsuraṁ pārtha me śhṛiṇu
shloks.simpleMeaning: There are two types of beings in this world: divine and demoniac. The divine has been described at length. Now hear from Me about the demoniac, O Partha.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Two fundamental orientations exist in humanity: toward the divine or toward the demoniac. Having described divine qualities, Krishna will now detail the demoniac mindset so we can recognize and avoid it.
shloks.strengthReflection: I orient myself toward the divine and learn to recognize the demoniac.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me about demoniac nature so I may avoid it.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुरासुराः। न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेषु विद्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: pravṛittiṁ cha nivṛittiṁ cha janā na vidur āsurāḥ na śhauchaṁ nāpi chāchāro na satyaṁ teṣhu vidyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: The demoniac do not know what to do and what not to do. Neither purity, nor right conduct, nor truth is found in them.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Demoniac people lack moral compass — they don't know right from wrong action. They have no inner or outer purity, no ethical conduct, no commitment to truth. This moral blindness defines the demoniac mindset.
shloks.strengthReflection: I maintain moral clarity, purity, ethical conduct, and commitment to truth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me always know right action and remain committed to truth.

shloks.sanskrit: असत्यमप्रतिष्ठं ते जगदाहुरनीश्वरम्। अपरस्परसंभूतं किमन्यत्कामहैतुकम्॥
shloks.transliteration: asatyam apratiṣhṭhaṁ te jagad āhur anīśhvaram aparaspara-sambhūtaṁ kim anyat kāma-haitukam
shloks.simpleMeaning: They say the world is unreal, without foundation, without a God, brought about by mutual union alone, caused by lust — what else?
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac worldview: the universe is unreal and meaningless, there is no God, everything arose randomly through material processes, desire (lust) is life's driving force. This philosophy leads to selfish, nihilistic behavior.
shloks.strengthReflection: I reject the view that life is meaningless and godless, driven only by desire.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I affirm that the world is real, purposeful, and You are its foundation.

shloks.sanskrit: एतां दृष्टिमवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानोऽल्पबुद्धयः। प्रभवन्त्युग्रकर्माणः क्षयाय जगतोऽहिताः॥
shloks.transliteration: etāṁ dṛiṣhṭim avaṣhṭabhya naṣhṭātmāno 'lpa-buddhayaḥ prabhavanty ugra-karmāṇaḥ kṣhayāya jagato 'hitāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and cruel deeds arise as enemies of the world for its destruction.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Embracing this nihilistic worldview, people of small understanding and lost souls become cruel, destructive forces. They harm the world because they see no meaning or consequence to their actions.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate wisdom and compassion, refusing to become a destructive force.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, protect me from nihilistic views that lead to cruelty and destruction.

shloks.sanskrit: काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः। मोहाद्गृहीत्वासद्ग्राहान्प्रवर्तन्तेऽशुचिव्रताः॥
shloks.transliteration: kāmam āśhritya duṣhpūraṁ dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ mohād gṛihītvāsad-grāhān pravartante 'śhuchi-vratāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Resorting to insatiable desire, filled with hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, they hold false views through delusion and act with impure resolves.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac are driven by endless desire (never satisfied), full of pretense, pride, and arrogance. Through delusion they hold wrong ideas, and their resolves are impure — aimed at selfish ends regardless of harm.
shloks.strengthReflection: I avoid insatiable desire, hypocrisy, and impure resolves.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, satisfy my soul so I am not driven by endless craving.

shloks.sanskrit: चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः। कामोपभोगपरमा एतावदिति निश्चिताः॥
shloks.transliteration: chintām aparimeyāṁ cha pralayāntām upāśhritāḥ kāmopabhoga-paramā etāvad iti niśhchitāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Beset by immeasurable anxieties ending only at death, regarding gratification of desires as the highest goal, convinced that is all there is...
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac carry endless worries until death. They consider sense gratification life's highest goal, believing nothing more exists. This shallow, anxious existence misses life's deeper purpose and peace.
shloks.strengthReflection: I recognize that sense pleasure is not life's highest goal — there is more.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from endless anxiety and the delusion that pleasure is all.

shloks.sanskrit: आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः। ईहन्ते कामभोगार्थमन्यायेनार्थसञ्चयान्॥
shloks.transliteration: āśhā-pāśha-śhatair baddhāḥ kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ īhante kāma-bhogārtham anyāyenārtha-sañchayān
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...bound by hundreds of cords of hope, given over to desire and anger, they strive to amass wealth by unjust means for the gratification of desires.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Bound by countless hopes and expectations, driven by desire and anger, the demoniac strive to accumulate wealth through any means — even unjust ones — all for sense enjoyment. This is spiritual bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek wealth through just means, not driven by endless desire and anger.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from the bondage of excessive hopes, desires, and anger.

shloks.sanskrit: इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम्। इदमस्तीदमपि मे भविष्यति पुनर्धनम्॥
shloks.transliteration: idam adya mayā labdham imaṁ prāpsye manoratham idam astīdam api me bhaviṣhyati punar dhanam
shloks.simpleMeaning: 'This I have gained today; this desire I shall fulfill; this wealth is mine, and this also shall be mine in the future...'
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac mindset in action: 'I got this today, I'll get that tomorrow; this is mine, that will be mine too.' Endless acquisition, possessiveness, and future-projecting desire characterize their thinking.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am content with what I have and don't obsess over future acquisitions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from the endless acquiring mind that thinks only of 'mine.'

shloks.sanskrit: असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि। ईश्वरोऽहमहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान्सुखी॥
shloks.transliteration: asau mayā hataḥ śhatrur haniṣhye chāparān api īśhvaro 'ham ahaṁ bhogī siddho 'haṁ balavān sukhī
shloks.simpleMeaning: 'That enemy has been slain by me, and I shall slay others too. I am the lord, I am the enjoyer, I am successful, powerful, and happy...'
shloks.practicalExplanation: More demoniac thinking: 'I destroyed my enemy, I'll destroy more; I am God/lord of my realm, I am the supreme enjoyer, I am accomplished, powerful, and happy.' This is extreme ego — seeing oneself as god.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am not the lord; God is. I am not the supreme enjoyer or controller.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, You are the true Lord and Enjoyer. I am Your humble servant.

shloks.sanskrit: आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया। यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्यज्ञानविमोहिताः॥
shloks.transliteration: āḍhyo 'bhijanavān asmi ko 'nyo 'sti sadṛiśho mayā yakṣhye dāsyāmi modiṣhya ity ajñāna-vimohitāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: 'I am wealthy and highborn. Who else is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices, I shall give charity, I shall rejoice' — thus deluded by ignorance.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac boast: 'I'm rich and well-born, who equals me? I'll do rituals to show off, give to be praised, and be happy in my superiority.' Even their charity and worship are ego-driven, deluded by ignorance.
shloks.strengthReflection: I perform worship and charity without ego, not for praise or superiority.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my worship and giving from all ego and desire for recognition.

shloks.sanskrit: अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः। प्रसक्ताः कामभोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ॥
shloks.transliteration: aneka-chitta-vibhrāntā moha-jāla-samāvṛitāḥ prasaktāḥ kāma-bhogeṣhu patanti narake 'śhuchau
shloks.simpleMeaning: Bewildered by many thoughts, covered in a net of delusion, addicted to sense gratification — they fall into a foul hell.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Result of demoniac living: mind scattered in confusion, trapped in delusion's web, addicted to pleasures — such beings fall to hellish states. Their own choices create their downfall.
shloks.strengthReflection: I maintain mental clarity, avoid delusion's trap, and don't become addicted to pleasures.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, protect me from the scattered mind and addiction that lead to suffering.

shloks.sanskrit: आत्मसंभाविताः स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः। यजन्ते नामयज्ञैस्ते दम्भेनाविधिपूर्वकम्॥
shloks.transliteration: ātma-sambhāvitāḥ stabdhā dhana-māna-madānvitāḥ yajante nāma-yajñais te dambhenāvidhi-pūrvakam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only with hypocrisy, disregarding the scriptural injunctions.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac are self-important, obstinate, drunk on wealth and pride. They perform religious acts for show only, hypocritically, without following proper guidelines. Their spirituality is fake, designed to impress.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice spiritual disciplines sincerely, not for show or without proper guidance.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my worship be genuine, humble, and in accordance with truth.

shloks.sanskrit: अहंकारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः। मामात्मपरदेहेषु प्रद्विषन्तोऽभ्यसूयकाः॥
shloks.transliteration: ahaṅkāraṁ balaṁ darpaṁ kāmaṁ krodhaṁ cha saṁśhritāḥ mām ātma-para-deheṣhu pradviṣhanto 'bhyasūyakāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Given over to ego, force, arrogance, desire, and anger, these envious persons hate Me in their own bodies and in those of others.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The demoniac cling to ego, brute force, pride, desire, and anger. Being envious, they hate the Divine presence in themselves and others. They reject the God within, which is ultimate self-destruction.
shloks.strengthReflection: I honor the Divine in myself and others, rejecting ego, force, and envy.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me never hate You within myself or others. Remove my envy.

shloks.sanskrit: तानहं द्विषतः क्रुरान्संसारेषु नराधमान्। क्षिपाम्यजस्रमशुभानासुरीष्वेव योनिषु॥
shloks.transliteration: tān ahaṁ dviṣhataḥ krūrān sansāreṣhu narādhamān kṣhipāmy ajasram aśhubhān āsurīṣhv eva yoniṣhu
shloks.simpleMeaning: These hateful, cruel, and vile people — the lowest of humanity — I repeatedly cast into demoniac wombs in the cycles of rebirth.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those who hate with cruelty, the lowest of humans, are repeatedly born into demoniac conditions. This isn't divine punishment but natural consequence — hateful consciousness attracts hateful circumstances.
shloks.strengthReflection: I choose love over hate, knowing that my consciousness shapes my future births.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, remove all hate and cruelty from me. Let me never fall to such births.

shloks.sanskrit: आसुरीं योनिमापन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि। मामप्राप्यैव कौन्तेय ततो यान्त्यधमां गतिम्॥
shloks.transliteration: āsurīṁ yonim āpannā mūḍhā janmani janmani mām aprāpyaiva kaunteya tato yānty adhamāṁ gatim
shloks.simpleMeaning: Entering demoniac wombs, deluded birth after birth, never reaching Me, O son of Kunti, they sink to the lowest condition.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Born repeatedly in demoniac conditions, these deluded beings never reach God. They spiral downward to ever lower states. Without divine connection, there's no way up — only further descent.
shloks.strengthReflection: I maintain my connection to God to avoid spiritual descent.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, keep me connected to You so I never fall into spiritual descent.

shloks.sanskrit: त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः। कामः क्रोधस्तथा लोभस्तस्मादेतत्त्रयं त्यजेत्॥
shloks.transliteration: tri-vidhaṁ narakasyedaṁ dvāraṁ nāśhanam ātmanaḥ kāmaḥ krodhas tathā lobhas tasmād etat trayaṁ tyajet
shloks.simpleMeaning: Three are the gates to this hell, destructive of the self: desire, anger, and greed. Therefore, one should abandon these three.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Three gates lead to hell and self-destruction: desire (kama), anger (krodha), and greed (lobha). These three must be abandoned. They are the root causes of demoniac nature and spiritual downfall.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work to overcome desire, anger, and greed — the three gates to hell.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me abandon desire, anger, and greed that destroy the soul.

shloks.sanskrit: एतैर्विमुक्तः कौन्तेय तमोद्वारैस्त्रिभिर्नरः। आचरत्यात्मनः श्रेयस्ततो याति परां गतिम्॥
shloks.transliteration: etair vimuktaḥ kaunteya tamo-dvārais tribhir naraḥ ācharaty ātmanaḥ śhreyas tato yāti parāṁ gatim
shloks.simpleMeaning: A person who is free from these three gates of darkness, O son of Kunti, practices what is good for the self and thus attains the supreme goal.
shloks.practicalExplanation: One who is freed from desire, anger, and greed — the three dark gates — can practice true self-welfare. Being free from these destructive forces, they attain the highest destination. Freedom from vice leads to liberation.
shloks.strengthReflection: Freed from desire, anger, and greed, I practice true self-welfare and attain the highest.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from these three gates of darkness so I may attain the supreme.

shloks.sanskrit: यः शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य वर्तते कामकारतः। न स सिद्धिमवाप्नोति न सुखं न परां गतिम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yaḥ śhāstra-vidhim utsṛijya vartate kāma-kārataḥ na sa siddhim avāpnoti na sukhaṁ na parāṁ gatim
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who discards scriptural injunctions and acts according to one's own desires attains neither perfection, nor happiness, nor the supreme goal.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Whoever abandons scriptural guidance and follows mere impulse gains neither perfection, happiness, nor the highest goal. Self-will without wisdom leads nowhere good. Scriptures provide the map; ignoring them, we get lost.
shloks.strengthReflection: I follow scriptural guidance rather than mere impulse to attain lasting good.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me follow Your guidance rather than my blind impulses.

shloks.sanskrit: तस्माच्छास्त्रं प्रमाणं ते कार्याकार्यव्यवस्थितौ। ज्ञात्वा शास्त्रविधानोक्तं कर्म कर्तुमिहार्हसि॥
shloks.transliteration: tasmāch chhāstraṁ pramāṇaṁ te kāryākārya-vyavasthitau jñātvā śhāstra-vidhānoktaṁ karma kartum ihārhasi
shloks.simpleMeaning: Therefore, let scripture be your authority in determining what should and should not be done. Knowing what is declared by scriptural injunctions, you should act accordingly.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Therefore, let scriptures be your guide for right action. Understanding what scriptures declare, act accordingly. This is the practical conclusion: follow revealed wisdom, not blind impulse or demoniac tendencies.
shloks.strengthReflection: I let scriptures guide me in determining right and wrong action.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, may Your revealed wisdom be my authority for action and life.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः। तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha ye śhāstra-vidhim utsṛijya yajante śhraddhayānvitāḥ teṣhāṁ niṣhṭhā tu kā kṛiṣhṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what is the condition of those who, setting aside scriptural injunctions, worship with faith? Is it sattva, rajas, or tamas?
shloks.practicalExplanation: Arjuna asks about those who worship sincerely but without following scripture. What determines their nature — their faith or their ignorance of rules? This opens a discussion on the role of faith (shraddha).
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine the quality of my faith beyond mere external observances.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, reveal to me the nature of true faith.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा। सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha tri-vidhā bhavati śhraddhā dehināṁ sā svabhāva-jā sāttvikī rājasī chaiva tāmasī cheti tāṁ śhṛiṇu
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: The faith of embodied beings is of three kinds, born of their nature — sattvic, rajasic, and tamasic. Hear about this.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna explains that faith comes in three varieties based on the person's innate nature (svabhava). Sattvic faith is pure, rajasic is passionate, tamasic is dark. Our fundamental disposition colors our faith.
shloks.strengthReflection: My faith reflects my nature; I cultivate sattvic (pure) faith.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, transform my nature so my faith becomes sattvic.

shloks.sanskrit: सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत। श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः॥
shloks.transliteration: sattvānurūpā sarvasya śhraddhā bhavati bhārata śhraddhā-mayo 'yaṁ puruṣho yo yach-chhraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The faith of each person accords with his nature, O Bharata. A person is made of faith — as is one's faith, so is one.
shloks.practicalExplanation: We become what we believe. Faith shapes our entire being. 'Shraddha-mayo' — a person is made of faith. As your faith is, so you are. This is profound: change your faith, change yourself.
shloks.strengthReflection: I am made of my faith. What I believe, I become.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my faith be in You so I may become godly.

shloks.sanskrit: यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान्यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः। प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः॥
shloks.transliteration: yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣha-rakṣhānsi rājasāḥ pretān bhūta-gaṇānśh chānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sattvic people worship the gods; rajasic ones worship demigods and demons; others, the tamasic, worship ghosts and spirits.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Faith determines what we worship: sattvic people worship divine beings (devatas), rajasic people worship powerful spirits for material gain, tamasic people worship ghosts and dark entities. Our object of worship reveals our nature.
shloks.strengthReflection: I direct my worship toward the highest divine, not toward lower beings.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my worship be directed only toward You, the highest.

shloks.sanskrit: अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः। दम्भाहंकारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः॥
shloks.transliteration: aśhāstra-vihitaṁ ghoraṁ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ dambhāhaṅkāra-saṁyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Those who perform severe austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egotism, impelled by desire and attachment...
shloks.practicalExplanation: Some perform extreme, non-scriptural austerities driven by ego, hypocrisy, desire, and attachment. Such practices, however severe, are not spiritual but ego-driven. True austerity follows wisdom, not willfulness.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice proper austerities guided by wisdom, not extreme ego-driven ones.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, guide my austerities according to Your wisdom, not my ego.

shloks.sanskrit: कर्षयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः। मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान्॥
shloks.transliteration: karṣhayantaḥ śharīra-sthaṁ bhūta-grāmam achetasaḥ māṁ chaivāntaḥ śharīra-sthaṁ tān viddhy āsura-niśhchayān
shloks.simpleMeaning: ...torturing the elements in the body and also Me dwelling within — know them to be of demoniac resolve.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those who torture the body's elements and thus torture the Divine within are of demoniac nature. God dwells in the body; self-harm is harming God's temple. Such extreme practices are condemned, not praised.
shloks.strengthReflection: I honor my body as God's dwelling, not tormenting it through extremism.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, dwelling within me, let me honor You by treating my body wisely.

shloks.sanskrit: आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः। यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं शृणु॥
shloks.transliteration: āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ yajñas tapas tathā dānaṁ teṣhāṁ bhedam imaṁ śhṛiṇu
shloks.simpleMeaning: Even the food that is dear to each is of three kinds. Likewise are sacrifice, austerity, and charity. Hear now the distinction between them.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Food preferences, worship styles, austerities, and charity all come in three types according to the gunas. Krishna will now explain each, giving practical guidance for everyday life choices.
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine my food, worship, discipline, and giving through the lens of the three gunas.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me to make sattvic choices in food, worship, austerity, and giving.

shloks.sanskrit: आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः। रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः॥
shloks.transliteration: āyuḥ-sattva-balārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛidyā āhārāḥ sāttvika-priyāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Foods that promote life, virtue, strength, health, happiness, and satisfaction, that are juicy, oily, wholesome, and pleasing to the heart — these are dear to the sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic foods increase life, purity, strength, health, happiness, and satisfaction. They are tasty (rasa), nourishing (snigdha), substantial (sthira), and heart-pleasing (hridya). Fresh, natural, balanced foods are sattvic.
shloks.strengthReflection: I choose sattvic foods that nourish life, health, and inner clarity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, guide my food choices toward purity and nourishment.

shloks.sanskrit: कट्वम्ललवणात्युष्णतीक्ष्णरूक्षविदाहिनः। आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःखशोकामयप्रदाः॥
shloks.transliteration: kaṭv-amla-lavaṇāty-uṣhṇa-tīkṣhṇa-rūkṣha-vidāhinaḥ āhārā rājasasyeṣhṭā duḥkha-śhokāmaya-pradāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Foods that are bitter, sour, salty, very hot, pungent, dry, and burning — these are dear to the rajasic and cause pain, grief, and disease.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajasic foods are excessively bitter, sour, salty, hot, spicy, dry, and burning. They stimulate but ultimately cause discomfort, emotional disturbance, and illness. These foods agitate rather than nourish.
shloks.strengthReflection: I moderate rajasic foods that cause agitation and discomfort.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me avoid foods that disturb my peace and health.

shloks.sanskrit: यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत्। उच्छिष्टमपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yāta-yāmaṁ gata-rasaṁ pūti paryuṣhitaṁ cha yat uchchhiṣhṭam api chāmedhyaṁ bhojanaṁ tāmasa-priyam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Food that is stale, tasteless, putrid, leftover, and impure — such food is dear to the tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamasic foods are stale, flavorless, rotten, leftover (from another's plate), and unclean. Such food promotes dullness, disease, and impurity. Fresh, clean food is essential for spiritual and physical health.
shloks.strengthReflection: I avoid tamasic foods that are stale, rotten, or impure.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me consume only what is fresh and pure.

shloks.sanskrit: अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदिष्टो य इज्यते। यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः॥
shloks.transliteration: aphalākāṅkṣhibhir yajño vidhi-diṣhṭo ya ijyate yaṣhṭavyam eveti manaḥ samādhāya sa sāttvikaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: That sacrifice which is offered according to scriptural injunctions, by those not desiring fruit, with the mind focused on the idea that it is one's duty to sacrifice — that is sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic worship follows scriptural guidelines, expects no reward, and is performed from duty alone. The mind is focused on the act itself, not on results. This is pure, ego-free worship.
shloks.strengthReflection: I worship without expecting rewards, focused on duty and devotion alone.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my worship be pure — duty-focused, reward-free, scripture-guided.

shloks.sanskrit: अभिसंधाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत्। इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम्॥
shloks.transliteration: abhisandhāya tu phalaṁ dambhārtham api chaiva yat ijyate bharata-śhreṣhṭha taṁ yajñaṁ viddhi rājasam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But that sacrifice which is offered with expectation of reward or for the sake of show, O best of the Bharatas — know it to be rajasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajasic worship is performed for results or for public display. The intention is either to gain something or to impress others. Though externally correct, the motive pollutes the act.
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine my worship to ensure it's not for show or reward.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my worship from all desire for reward or recognition.

shloks.sanskrit: विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम्। श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते॥
shloks.transliteration: vidhi-hīnam asṛiṣhṭānnaṁ mantra-hīnam adakṣhiṇam śhraddhā-virahitaṁ yajñaṁ tāmasaṁ parichakṣhate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Sacrifice performed without regard to scriptural injunctions, without distribution of food, without mantras, without gifts to priests, and without faith — that is declared to be tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamasic worship ignores proper guidelines, offers no sharing of food, lacks sacred sounds, gives no donation, and has no faith. It's worship in form only — empty, mechanical, meaningless ritual.
shloks.strengthReflection: I ensure my worship has proper form, content, and sincere faith.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my worship be complete — proper, generous, and faith-filled.

shloks.sanskrit: देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम्। ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjanaṁ śhaucham ārjavam brahmacharyam ahiṁsā cha śhārīraṁ tapa uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Worship of the gods, the twice-born, teachers, and the wise; purity, uprightness, celibacy, and non-violence — this is called austerity of the body.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Physical austerity (tapas) includes: worshipping the divine and teachers, maintaining bodily purity, living with integrity, practicing appropriate celibacy, and non-violence. These bodily disciplines purify the physical being.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice physical austerity: honor teachers, maintain purity, integrity, and non-violence.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me discipline my body in worship, purity, and non-violence.

shloks.sanskrit: अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत्। स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: anudvega-karaṁ vākyaṁ satyaṁ priya-hitaṁ cha yat svādhyāyābhyasanaṁ chaiva vāṅ-mayaṁ tapa uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Speech that causes no distress, that is truthful, pleasant, and beneficial, as well as regular recitation of scriptures — this is called austerity of speech.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Speech austerity means: words that don't agitate others, truthful speech, words that are pleasant AND beneficial (not just nice), and regular study/recitation of sacred texts. Control of speech is powerful discipline.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice speech austerity: non-disturbing, truthful, pleasant, beneficial, scriptural.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, discipline my speech to be truthful, kind, and spiritually aligned.

shloks.sanskrit: मनःप्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः। भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: manaḥ-prasādaḥ saumyatvaṁ maunam ātma-vinigrahaḥ bhāva-sanśhuddhir ity etat tapo mānasam uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Serenity of mind, gentleness, silence, self-control, and purity of being — this is called austerity of the mind.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Mental austerity includes: peaceful mind (prasada), gentle disposition (saumya), appropriate silence (mauna), self-control, and purity of intention. These inner disciplines are the subtlest and most powerful.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice mental austerity: serenity, gentleness, silence, control, pure intention.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, make my mind serene, gentle, controlled, and pure.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः। अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते॥
shloks.transliteration: śhraddhayā parayā taptaṁ tapas tat tri-vidhaṁ naraiḥ aphalākāṅkṣhibhir yuktaiḥ sāttvikaṁ parichakṣhate
shloks.simpleMeaning: This threefold austerity, practiced with supreme faith by people who are not desirous of fruit and who are steadfast — is called sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: When all three forms of austerity (body, speech, mind) are practiced with supreme faith, without desire for reward, by steady practitioners — that is sattvic austerity. Faith and selflessness elevate discipline.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice body, speech, and mind disciplines with faith and without expecting reward.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my austerities be sattvic — faith-filled and selfless.

shloks.sanskrit: सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत्। क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम्॥
shloks.transliteration: satkāra-māna-pūjārthaṁ tapo dambhena chaiva yat kriyate tad iha proktaṁ rājasaṁ chalam adhruvam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Austerity performed for the sake of gaining respect, honor, and reverence, and with hypocrisy — is said to be rajasic, unstable, and impermanent.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Austerity done for reputation, honor, worship from others, or with hypocrisy is rajasic. Its results are unstable and temporary. When ego drives discipline, the benefits fade quickly.
shloks.strengthReflection: I practice austerity for spiritual growth, not for recognition or praise.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my disciplines from the desire for honor and recognition.

shloks.sanskrit: मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः। परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: mūḍha-grāheṇātmano yat pīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ parasyotsādanārthaṁ vā tat tāmasam udāhṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: Austerity performed with foolish obstinacy, with self-torture, or for the purpose of harming another — that is declared to be tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamasic austerity is done with stubborn foolishness, tortures oneself, or aims to harm others. Self-mortification from ignorance or practices to gain power over others are spiritually destructive.
shloks.strengthReflection: I reject foolish, self-torturing, or harmful forms of austerity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, protect me from misguided practices that harm myself or others.

shloks.sanskrit: दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे। देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: dātavyam iti yad dānaṁ dīyate 'nupakāriṇe deśhe kāle cha pātre cha tad dānaṁ sāttvikaṁ smṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: That gift which is given with the thought 'it is one's duty to give,' to a worthy person who can give nothing in return, at the right place and time — that is considered sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic giving: done from duty, to those who cannot repay, at appropriate time and place, to worthy recipients. It expects nothing in return — neither material reward nor even gratitude. Pure giving.
shloks.strengthReflection: I give from duty to worthy recipients who cannot return the favor.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my giving be pure — duty-based, selfless, appropriate.

shloks.sanskrit: यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः। दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yat tu pratyupakārārthaṁ phalam uddiśhya vā punaḥ dīyate cha parikliṣhṭaṁ tad dānaṁ rājasaṁ smṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But that gift which is given with expectation of return, or with a desire for fruit, or reluctantly — that is considered rajasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajasic giving expects something back — return favor, reward, or recognition. It may also be given reluctantly, with regret or resentment. The inner resistance or expectation pollutes the gift.
shloks.strengthReflection: I give without expecting return, reward, or recognition.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my giving from all expectation and reluctance.

shloks.sanskrit: अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते। असत्कृतमवज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: adeśha-kāle yad dānam apātrebhyaśh cha dīyate asatkṛitam avajñātaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: That gift which is given at the wrong place and time, to unworthy persons, without respect, or with contempt — that is declared to be tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamasic giving is wrong in place, time, or recipient. It's given disrespectfully or contemptuously — humiliating the receiver. Such giving may do more harm than good and creates negative karma.
shloks.strengthReflection: I give at the right time, to worthy recipients, with respect and honor.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me give wisely, respectfully, and appropriately.

shloks.sanskrit: ओं तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः। ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा॥
shloks.transliteration: oṁ tat sad iti nirdeśho brahmaṇas tri-vidhaḥ smṛitaḥ brāhmaṇās tena vedāśh cha yajñāśh cha vihitāḥ purā
shloks.simpleMeaning: 'Om Tat Sat' — this is declared to be the threefold designation of Brahman. By that, the Brahmanas, the Vedas, and the sacrifices were ordained in ancient times.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The sacred formula 'Om Tat Sat' designates the Supreme. Om is the primal sound, Tat means 'That' (the absolute), Sat means 'Truth/Being.' By this, all sacred traditions were established. These words sanctify all spiritual acts.
shloks.strengthReflection: I invoke 'Om Tat Sat' to connect my actions to the Supreme.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let 'Om Tat Sat' sanctify all my spiritual practices.

shloks.sanskrit: तस्माद्ओमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः। प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम्॥
shloks.transliteration: tasmād om ity udāhṛitya yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṁ brahma-vādinām
shloks.simpleMeaning: Therefore, acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity prescribed by the scriptures are always begun by the knowers of Brahman with the utterance of 'Om.'
shloks.practicalExplanation: Those who know Brahman begin all scriptural acts — worship, giving, discipline — with 'Om.' This sacred syllable connects the action to the Supreme, elevating mundane acts to spiritual offerings.
shloks.strengthReflection: I begin my spiritual practices with 'Om,' connecting them to the Supreme.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let 'Om' connect all my actions to You.

shloks.sanskrit: तदित्यनभिसंधाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः। दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभिः॥
shloks.transliteration: tad ity anabhisandhāya phalaṁ yajña-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ dāna-kriyāśh cha vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣha-kāṅkṣhibhiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Without desire for fruit, acts of sacrifice, austerity, and various acts of charity are performed by those seeking liberation with the word 'Tat.'
shloks.practicalExplanation: Liberation-seekers perform worship, discipline, and charity with 'Tat' (That) — acknowledging these acts belong to the Absolute, not to the ego. 'Tat' removes the sense of personal doership and ownership.
shloks.strengthReflection: I dedicate my actions with 'Tat,' recognizing they belong to the Absolute.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, all my actions are 'Tat' — Yours, not mine.

shloks.sanskrit: सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते। प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: sad-bhāve sādhu-bhāve cha sad ity etat prayujyate praśhaste karmaṇi tathā sach-chhabdaḥ pārtha yujyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: 'Sat' is used to denote reality and goodness. Likewise, O Partha, the word 'Sat' is used for auspicious action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: 'Sat' means truth, reality, and goodness. It's used for whatever is real, virtuous, and auspicious. Invoking 'Sat' affirms the action's truth and goodness, aligning it with eternal reality.
shloks.strengthReflection: I invoke 'Sat' to affirm the truth and goodness of my actions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let all my actions be 'Sat' — true, real, and good.

shloks.sanskrit: यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते। कर्म चैव तदर्थीयं सदित्येवाभिधीयते॥
shloks.transliteration: yajñe tapasi dāne cha sthitiḥ sad iti chochyate karma chaiva tad-arthīyaṁ sad ity evābhidhīyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity, and charity is also called 'Sat.' And action performed for their sake is likewise called 'Sat.'
shloks.practicalExplanation: Steadfastness in worship, discipline, and giving is 'Sat.' Actions done for these purposes are also 'Sat.' The firm commitment to spiritual practices is itself truth and goodness.
shloks.strengthReflection: My steadfast commitment to spiritual practice is 'Sat' — truth itself.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me be steadfast in worship, discipline, and giving.

shloks.sanskrit: अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत्। असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह॥
shloks.transliteration: aśhraddhayā hutaṁ dattaṁ tapas taptaṁ kṛitaṁ cha yat asad ity uchyate pārtha na cha tat pretya no iha
shloks.simpleMeaning: Whatever offering, gift, austerity, or action is performed without faith is called 'Asat,' O Partha. It is of no avail here or hereafter.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Whatever is done without faith — sacrifice, charity, discipline, or any action — is 'Asat' (unreal, untrue). It yields no benefit in this life or the next. Faith (shraddha) is essential; without it, actions are empty.
shloks.strengthReflection: I ensure all my actions are backed by sincere faith.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, fill my actions with faith so they are not empty and fruitless.

shloks.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। संन्यासस्य महाबाहो तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम्। त्यागस्य च हृषीकेश पृथक्केशिनिषूदन॥
shloks.transliteration: arjuna uvācha sannyāsasya mahā-bāho tattvam ichchhāmi veditum tyāgasya cha hṛiṣhīkeśha pṛithak keśhi-niṣhūdana
shloks.simpleMeaning: Arjuna said: O mighty-armed one, O Hrishikesha, O slayer of Keshi, I wish to know the truth of renunciation (sannyasa) and relinquishment (tyaga) separately.
shloks.practicalExplanation: In this final chapter, Arjuna asks about the distinction between sannyasa (renunciation of actions) and tyaga (relinquishment of fruits). This inquiry will lead to the Gita's ultimate teaching on liberation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek to understand the true meaning of renunciation and letting go.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me the final truth about renunciation that leads to freedom.

shloks.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। काम्यानां कर्मणां न्यासं संन्यासं कवयो विदुः। सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं प्राहुस्त्यागं विचक्षणाः॥
shloks.transliteration: śhrī bhagavān uvācha kāmyānāṁ karmaṇāṁ nyāsaṁ sannyāsaṁ kavayo viduḥ sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ prāhus tyāgaṁ vichakṣhaṇāḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The Supreme Lord said: The wise understand sannyasa as the abandonment of desire-motivated actions. The discerning speak of tyaga as the relinquishment of the fruits of all actions.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna clarifies: sannyasa means giving up actions done for personal desire. Tyaga means giving up attachment to results of all actions. One abandons selfish actions; the other abandons selfish expectation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I give up desire-driven actions and attachment to results of all actions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me understand true renunciation — of selfish actions and their fruits.

shloks.sanskrit: त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः। यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यमिति चापरे॥
shloks.transliteration: tyājyaṁ doṣhavad ity eke karma prāhur manīṣhiṇaḥ yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyam iti chāpare
shloks.simpleMeaning: Some philosophers declare that all action should be abandoned as evil; others say that acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should not be relinquished.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Different schools have different views: some say give up all action as inherently flawed; others say sacrifice, charity, and austerity should never be given up. Krishna will give the definitive teaching.
shloks.strengthReflection: I seek Krishna's definitive teaching beyond varying philosophical opinions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, give me clarity beyond conflicting views on action and renunciation.

shloks.sanskrit: निश्चयं शृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम। त्यागो हि पुरुषव्याघ्र त्रिविधः संप्रकीर्तितः॥
shloks.transliteration: niśhchayaṁ śhṛiṇu me tatra tyāge bharata-sattama tyāgo hi puruṣha-vyāghra tri-vidhaḥ samprakīrtitaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Hear My conclusion on the matter of relinquishment, O best of Bharatas. Relinquishment, O tiger among men, is declared to be of three kinds.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna will now give His definitive conclusion on tyaga (relinquishment). It comes in three types based on the three gunas. This teaches practical discrimination in renunciation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I hear Krishna's definitive teaching on relinquishment.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me the three types of relinquishment so I may choose wisely.

shloks.sanskrit: यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत्। यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyaṁ kāryam eva tat yajño dānaṁ tapaśh chaiva pāvanāni manīṣhiṇām
shloks.simpleMeaning: Acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should not be abandoned; they must be performed. Indeed, sacrifice, charity, and austerity are purifiers of the wise.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna's clear verdict: sacrifice, charity, and austerity must never be abandoned — they must be performed. These actions purify even the wise. They are essential duties, not optional extras.
shloks.strengthReflection: I continue sacrifice, charity, and austerity as essential purifying duties.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I will never abandon sacrifice, charity, and discipline that purify me.

shloks.sanskrit: एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च। कर्तव्यानीति मे पार्थ निश्चितं मतमुत्तमम्॥
shloks.transliteration: etāny api tu karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalāni cha kartavyānīti me pārtha niśhchitaṁ matam uttamam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But even these actions should be performed giving up attachment and desire for fruits — this is My definite and supreme conclusion, O Partha.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna's supreme conclusion: perform these duties but give up attachment and desire for results. Action with detachment — this is the highest path. Neither inaction nor attached action, but detached action.
shloks.strengthReflection: I perform duties while giving up attachment to results — this is supreme.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I accept Your supreme conclusion: act without attachment.

shloks.sanskrit: नियतस्य तु संन्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते। मोहात्तस्य परित्यागस्तामसः परिकीर्तितः॥
shloks.transliteration: niyatasya tu sannyāsaḥ karmaṇo nopapadyate mohāt tasya parityāgas tāmasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Renunciation of obligatory duties is not proper. The abandonment of such duties through delusion is declared to be tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: It's wrong to abandon prescribed duties. Giving up obligations through confusion or laziness is tamasic renunciation — the worst kind. Duty cannot be escaped through misunderstanding.
shloks.strengthReflection: I never abandon my duties through confusion or laziness.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, protect me from tamasic renunciation that abandons essential duties.

shloks.sanskrit: दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत्। स कृत्वा राजसं त्यागं नैव त्यागफलं लभेत्॥
shloks.transliteration: duḥkham ity eva yat karma kāya-kleśha-bhayāt tyajet sa kṛitvā rājasaṁ tyāgaṁ naiva tyāga-phalaṁ labhet
shloks.simpleMeaning: One who abandons action because it is painful or from fear of bodily discomfort — practicing such rajasic renunciation, one does not gain the fruit of renunciation.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Giving up action because it's difficult or physically uncomfortable is rajasic renunciation. This avoidance of hardship brings no spiritual benefit. True renunciation isn't about avoiding effort.
shloks.strengthReflection: I don't abandon duties just because they're hard or uncomfortable.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, strengthen me to embrace duty despite difficulty.

shloks.sanskrit: कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन। सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः॥
shloks.transliteration: kāryam ity eva yat karma niyataṁ kriyate 'rjuna saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalaṁ chaiva sa tyāgaḥ sāttviko mataḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: When obligatory action is performed merely because it ought to be done, O Arjuna, giving up attachment and fruit — that renunciation is considered sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic renunciation: performing duty because it should be done, while giving up attachment and desire for results. The action is done; the attachment is released. This is true, pure renunciation.
shloks.strengthReflection: I perform duty because it should be done, free from attachment to results.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let my renunciation be sattvic — duty with detachment.

shloks.sanskrit: न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते। त्यागी सत्त्वसमाविष्टो मेधावी छिन्नसंशयः॥
shloks.transliteration: na dveṣhṭy akuśhalaṁ karma kuśhale nānuṣhajjate tyāgī sattva-samāviṣhṭo medhāvī chhinna-sanśhayaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The wise relinquisher, imbued with sattva, with doubts cut away, neither hates unpleasant action nor is attached to pleasant action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The wise person with sattvic renunciation doesn't hate difficult duties or cling to pleasant ones. Imbued with clarity, doubts resolved, they act with equanimity. This is the mark of true wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I neither hate unpleasant duties nor cling to pleasant ones — I act with equanimity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, fill me with sattva so I act without preference or aversion.

shloks.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः। यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते॥
shloks.transliteration: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abhidhīyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: It is not possible for one who has a body to completely abandon action. But one who relinquishes the fruits of action is called a true relinquisher.
shloks.practicalExplanation: While embodied, complete inaction is impossible — even breathing and thinking are actions. True renunciation is giving up attachment to results, not giving up action itself. This practical wisdom applies to everyone.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cannot abandon all action; I can abandon attachment to results.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, I am a true tyagi by releasing attachment to the fruits of action.

shloks.sanskrit: अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम्। भवत्यत्यागिनां प्रेत्य न तु संन्यासिनां क्वचित्॥
shloks.transliteration: aniṣhṭam iṣhṭaṁ miśhraṁ cha tri-vidhaṁ karmaṇaḥ phalam bhavaty atyāgināṁ pretya na tu sannyāsināṁ kvachit
shloks.simpleMeaning: The threefold fruit of action — undesirable, desirable, and mixed — accrues after death to those who do not renounce, but never to the renouncers.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Actions bear fruit: bad, good, or mixed. Those attached to results experience these fruits after death. True renouncers, free from attachment, accumulate no karmic results. Detachment frees from karmic bondage.
shloks.strengthReflection: By releasing attachment to results, I free myself from karmic accumulation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me be a true renouncer, free from karmic consequences.

shloks.sanskrit: पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे। साङ्ख्ये कृतान्ते प्रोक्तानि सिद्धये सर्वकर्मणाम्॥
shloks.transliteration: pañchaitāni mahā-bāho kāraṇāni nibodha me sāṅkhye kṛitānte proktāni siddhaye sarva-karmaṇām
shloks.simpleMeaning: Learn from Me, O mighty-armed one, these five causes for the accomplishment of all action, as declared in the Sankhya teaching.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna teaches the five factors required for any action's accomplishment, as per the analytical Sankhya philosophy. Understanding these helps dissolve the false sense of personal doership.
shloks.strengthReflection: I learn the five causes of action to understand how actions truly occur.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me the factors of action so I may transcend false doership.

shloks.sanskrit: अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम्। विविधाश्च पृथक्चेष्टा दैवं चैवात्र पञ्चमम्॥
shloks.transliteration: adhiṣhṭhānaṁ tathā kartā karaṇaṁ cha pṛithag-vidham vividhāśh cha pṛithak cheṣhṭā daivaṁ chaivātra pañchamam
shloks.simpleMeaning: The seat of action (body), the doer (ego), the various instruments (senses), the many different kinds of efforts, and destiny as the fifth.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The five factors: (1) body/basis, (2) doer/ego, (3) instruments/senses, (4) various efforts, (5) destiny/divine will. All five must combine for any action. The ego alone doesn't accomplish anything.
shloks.strengthReflection: I see action arising from five factors, not from my ego alone.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, help me see that You as destiny are the fifth factor in all action.

shloks.sanskrit: शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः। न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः॥
shloks.transliteration: śharīra-vāṅ-manobhir yat karma prārabhate naraḥ nyāyyaṁ vā viparītaṁ vā pañchaite tasya hetavaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Whatever action a person performs by body, speech, or mind — whether right or wrong — these five are its causes.
shloks.practicalExplanation: All actions — bodily, verbal, mental, whether righteous or unrighteous — arise from these five factors. This analysis removes the burden of personal doership while clarifying how actions actually occur.
shloks.strengthReflection: All my actions arise from five factors; I am not the sole doer.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, seeing the five causes, I release the pride of personal doership.

shloks.sanskrit: तत्रैवं सति कर्तारमात्मानं केवलं तु यः। पश्यत्यकृतबुद्धित्वान्न स पश्यति दुर्मतिः॥
shloks.transliteration: tatraivaṁ sati kartāram ātmānaṁ kevalaṁ tu yaḥ paśhyaty akṛita-buddhitvān na sa paśhyati durmatiḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Therefore, one who, due to impure understanding, sees the self alone as the doer — that person of perverted intelligence does not see rightly.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Given these five factors, thinking 'I alone am the doer' is ignorance. Such perverted understanding misses the truth of how actions occur. True seeing includes all five factors.
shloks.strengthReflection: I don't see myself as the sole doer — that is ignorant understanding.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my understanding so I see correctly how actions occur.

shloks.sanskrit: यस्य नाहंकृतो भावो बुद्धिर्यस्य न लिप्यते। हत्वापि स इमाँल्लोकान्न हन्ति न निबध्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: yasya nāhaṅkṛito bhāvo buddhir yasya na lipyate hatvāpi sa imān lokān na hanti na nibadhyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: One whose mind is free from ego, whose understanding is untainted — even slaying these people, he neither kills nor is bound.
shloks.practicalExplanation: One free from ego-notion, with untainted intellect, even if acting in war, neither truly kills nor incurs karma. Without ego-identification, action happens but doesn't bind. This is the secret of free action.
shloks.strengthReflection: Free from ego and with pure understanding, I act without being bound.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from ego so my actions don't bind me.

shloks.sanskrit: ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं परिज्ञाता त्रिविधा कर्मचोदना। करणं कर्म कर्तेति त्रिविधः कर्मसंग्रहः॥
shloks.transliteration: jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ parijñātā tri-vidhā karma-chodanā karaṇaṁ karma karteti tri-vidhaḥ karma-saṅgrahaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: Knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the knower — these three motivate action. The instrument, the action, and the doer — these three constitute action.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Three factors motivate action: knowledge, its object, and the knower. Three constitute action: instruments, the deed, and the doer. This breakdown helps understand the complete mechanism of action.
shloks.strengthReflection: I understand the threefold motivation and constitution of action.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let me understand action completely through this analysis.

shloks.sanskrit: ज्ञानं कर्म च कर्ता च त्रिधैव गुणभेदतः। प्रोच्यते गुणसंख्याने यथावच्छृणु तान्यपि॥
shloks.transliteration: jñānaṁ karma cha kartā cha tridhaiva guṇa-bhedataḥ prochyate guṇa-saṅkhyāne yathāvach chhrṇu tāny api
shloks.simpleMeaning: Knowledge, action, and the doer are said to be of three kinds according to the distinction of gunas in the Sankhya teaching. Hear properly about these also.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Knowledge, action, and doer each come in three types based on the gunas. Understanding these helps identify our current state and aspire toward the sattvic. Krishna will now detail each.
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine my knowledge, action, and sense of doership through the three gunas.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me to recognize and cultivate sattvic knowledge, action, and doership.

shloks.sanskrit: सर्वभूतेषु येनैकं भावमव्ययमीक्षते। अविभक्तं विभक्तेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि सात्त्विकम्॥
shloks.transliteration: sarva-bhūteṣhu yenaikaṁ bhāvam avyayam īkṣhate avibhaktaṁ vibhakteṣhu taj jñānaṁ viddhi sāttvikam
shloks.simpleMeaning: That knowledge by which one sees the one imperishable reality in all beings, undivided among the divided — know that knowledge to be sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic knowledge sees one unchanging reality in all diverse beings — the undivided in the divided. This unifying vision perceives the eternal Self in all. It's the highest, most liberating knowledge.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate knowledge that sees the one imperishable reality in all beings.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me sattvic knowledge that sees You undivided in all.

shloks.sanskrit: पृथक्त्वेन तु यज्ज्ञानं नानाभावान्पृथग्विधान्। वेत्ति सर्वेषु भूतेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि राजसम्॥
shloks.transliteration: pṛithaktvena tu yaj jñānaṁ nānā-bhāvān pṛithag-vidhān vetti sarveṣhu bhūteṣhu taj jñānaṁ viddhi rājasam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But that knowledge which sees in all beings diverse entities of various kinds as separate — know that knowledge to be rajasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajasic knowledge sees separate, diverse entities everywhere — no underlying unity. It perceives multiplicity without recognizing the one Self. This fragmented vision misses the deeper reality.
shloks.strengthReflection: I move beyond knowledge that sees only separation and diversity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, lift my knowledge above the rajasic fragmented view.

shloks.sanskrit: यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहैतुकम्। अतत्त्वार्थवदल्पं च तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yat tu kṛitsna-vad ekasmin kārye saktam ahaitukam atattvārthavad alpaṁ cha tat tāmasam udāhṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But that knowledge which clings to one single effect as if it were everything, without reason, without basis in truth, and trivial — that is declared to be tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamasic knowledge obsesses over one thing as if it's all that matters — unreasonable, baseless, missing the big picture. It's narrow, irrational, and truth-lacking. The most ignorant form of knowing.
shloks.strengthReflection: I avoid narrow, irrational knowledge that misses the larger truth.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, protect me from tamasic knowledge that clings and misses truth.

shloks.sanskrit: नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम्। अफलप्रेप्सुना कर्म यत्तत्सात्त्विकमुच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: niyataṁ saṅga-rahitam arāga-dveṣhataḥ kṛitam aphala-prepsunā karma yat tat sāttvikam uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: Action that is obligatory, performed without attachment, without attraction or aversion, by one not desiring fruit — that is called sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic action is: obligatory (duty-based), done without attachment, performed without like or dislike, without desiring results. This is the purest form of action — free, selfless, duty-centered.
shloks.strengthReflection: I perform duty without attachment, preference, or desire for reward.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, let all my actions be sattvic — free and selfless.

shloks.sanskrit: यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहंकारेण वा पुनः। क्रियते बहुलायासं तद्राजसमुदाहृतम्॥
shloks.transliteration: yat tu kāmepsunā karma sāhaṅkāreṇa vā punaḥ kriyate bahulāyāsaṁ tad rājasam udāhṛitam
shloks.simpleMeaning: But action performed with desire for fruit, or with egotism, or with much effort — that is declared to be rajasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajasic action is driven by personal desire, ego, or excessive strain. Even good deeds become rajasic when motivated by 'what's in it for me?' or 'look how hard I'm trying.' The motive pollutes.
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine whether ego or desire for reward drives my actions.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, purify my actions from ego and self-interest.

shloks.sanskrit: अनुबन्धं क्षयं हिंसामनपेक्ष्य च पौरुषम्। मोहादारभ्यते कर्म यत्तत्तामसमुच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: anubandhaṁ kṣhayaṁ hiṁsām anapekṣhya cha pauruṣham mohād ārabhyate karma yat tat tāmasam uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: That action which is begun from delusion, disregarding consequences, loss, harm, and one's own capacity — that is called tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Tamasic action ignores consequences, potential loss, harm to others, and one's own ability. It's done from delusion — without thinking. Reckless, harmful, thoughtless action is the worst kind.
shloks.strengthReflection: I consider consequences, harm, and my capacity before acting — not from delusion.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, protect me from deluded action that ignores harm and consequences.

shloks.sanskrit: मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योर्निर्विकारः कर्ता सात्त्विक उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: mukta-saṅgo 'nahaṁ-vādī dhṛity-utsāha-samanvitaḥ siddhy-asiddhyor nirvikāraḥ kartā sāttvika uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: The doer who is free from attachment, not egotistic, endowed with determination and enthusiasm, unaffected by success or failure — is called sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The sattvic doer is: attachment-free, non-egotistic, determined, enthusiastic, and unchanged by success or failure. This is the ideal — engaged but detached, active but equanimous.
shloks.strengthReflection: I strive to be free from attachment and ego, determined yet unaffected by results.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, make me a sattvic doer — engaged, free, and equanimous.

shloks.sanskrit: रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः। हर्षशोकान्वितः कर्ता राजसः परिकीर्तितः॥
shloks.transliteration: rāgī karma-phala-prepsur lubdho hiṁsātmako 'śhuchiḥ harṣha-śhokānvitaḥ kartā rājasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ
shloks.simpleMeaning: The doer who is attached, desirous of action's fruits, greedy, violent by nature, impure, subject to joy and sorrow — is declared to be rajasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The rajasic doer is: attached, result-craving, greedy, potentially harmful, impure, and swings between elation and depression based on outcomes. Emotional instability marks this doer.
shloks.strengthReflection: I work to overcome attachment, greed, and emotional swings in my doership.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from rajasic doership with its attachments and instability.

shloks.sanskrit: अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकोऽलसः। विषादी दीर्घसूत्री च कर्ता तामस उच्यते॥
shloks.transliteration: ayuktaḥ prākṛitaḥ stabdhaḥ śhaṭho naiṣhkṛitiko 'lasaḥ viṣhādī dīrgha-sūtrī cha kartā tāmasa uchyate
shloks.simpleMeaning: The doer who is undisciplined, vulgar, stubborn, deceitful, malicious, lazy, despondent, and procrastinating — is called tamasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: The tamasic doer is: lacking self-control, crude, obstinate, dishonest, harmful, lazy, depressed, and always delaying. This is the lowest type of agency — destructive to self and others.
shloks.strengthReflection: I reject tamasic qualities: laziness, deceit, procrastination, and negativity.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, free me from all tamasic tendencies in my nature.

shloks.sanskrit: बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं शृणु। प्रोच्यमानमशेषेण पृथक्त्वेन धनञ्जय॥
shloks.transliteration: buddher bhedaṁ dhṛiteśh chaiva guṇatas tri-vidhaṁ śhṛiṇu prochyamānam aśheṣheṇa pṛithaktvena dhanañjaya
shloks.simpleMeaning: Hear now the threefold division of intellect (buddhi) and of steadiness (dhriti) according to the gunas, declared completely and separately, O Dhananjaya.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Krishna will now explain three types of intellect (discriminating understanding) and steadiness (determination) based on the gunas. This helps refine our inner faculties.
shloks.strengthReflection: I examine the quality of my intellect and determination.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, teach me about sattvic intellect and steadiness.

shloks.sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये। बन्धं मोक्षं च या वेत्ति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी॥
shloks.transliteration: pravṛittiṁ cha nivṛittiṁ cha kāryākārye bhayābhaye bandhaṁ mokṣhaṁ cha yā vetti buddhiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī
shloks.simpleMeaning: That intellect which knows action and inaction, what ought to be done and what ought not to be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation — that intellect, O Partha, is sattvic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Sattvic intellect correctly discerns: when to act and when not to, right from wrong action, proper fear from baseless fear, what binds and what liberates. This is discriminating wisdom.
shloks.strengthReflection: I cultivate intellect that discerns right action, proper fear, and liberation.
shloks.devotionalSurrender: O Lord, grant me sattvic intellect that knows what leads to freedom.

shloks.sanskrit: यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च। अयथावत्प्रजानाति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ राजसी॥
shloks.transliteration: yayā dharmam adharmaṁ cha kāryaṁ chākāryam eva cha ayathāvat prajānāti buddhiḥ sā pārtha rājasī
shloks.simpleMeaning: That intellect which imperfectly knows dharma from adharma, what ought to be done from what ought not to be done — that intellect, O Partha, is rajasic.
shloks.practicalExplanation: Rajasic intellect has confused, imperfect understanding of right and wrong, proper and improper action. It's partially correct but makes mistakes — clouded by passion and desire.
